title: Turán number of complete multipartite graphs in multipartite graphs

sections.text:
#### Abstract

In this paper we study a multi-partite version of the Erdős-Stone theorem. Given integers $r<k$ and $t \geqslant 1$, let $\exp _{k}\left(n, K_{r+1}(t)\right)$ be the maximum number of edges of $K_{r+1}(t)$-free $k$-partite graphs with $n$ vertices in each part, where $K_{r+1}(t)$ is the complete $(r+1)$-partite graph with $t$ vertices in each part. We determine the exact value of $\exp _{k}\left(n, K_{r+1}(t)\right)$ for $t \leqslant 3, r<k \leqslant 2 r$ and sufficiently large $n$. We also characterize all extremal graphs for $r, k$ such that $r$ divides $k$, analogous to a result of Erdős and Simonovits on forbidding $K_{r+1}(t)$ in general graphs.

## 1. InTRODUCTION

Generalizing Mantel's theorem from 1907 [18], Turán's theorem from 1941 [23] started the systemetic study of Extremal Graph Theory. Given a graph $F$, let $\operatorname{ex}(n, F)$ denote the largest number of edges in a graph not containing $F$ as a subgraph (called $F$-free). Let $K_{r}$ denote the complete graph on $r$ vertices and $T_{r}(n)$ denote the complete $r$-partite graph on $n$ vertices with $[n / r]$ or $[n / r]$ in each part (known as the Turán graph); and $t_{r}(n)$ be the size of $T_{r}(n)$. Turán's theorem [23] states that $\operatorname{ex}\left(n, K_{r+1}\right)=t_{r}(n)$ for all $n \geqslant r \geqslant 1$ and in addition, $T_{r}(n)$ is the unique extremal graph.

Let $K_{t_{1}, \ldots, t_{r}}$ denote the complete $r$-partite graph with parts of size $t_{1}, \ldots, t_{r}$ and write $K_{r}(t)=$ $K_{t, \ldots, t}$ with $r$ parts. A celebrated result of Erdős and Stone [10] determines $\operatorname{ex}\left(n, K_{r+1}(t)\right)$ asymptotically:

$$
\operatorname{ex}\left(n, K_{r+1}(t)\right)=t_{r}(n)+o\left(n^{2}\right)=\left(1-\frac{1}{r}\right) \frac{n^{2}}{2}+o\left(n^{2}\right)
$$

Erdős [7] and Simonovits [21] independently improved the error term above to $O\left(n^{2-1 / t}\right)$. Simonovits [21] also showed that any extremal graph for $K_{r+1}(t)$ can be obtained from $T_{r}(n)$ by adding or removing $O\left(n^{2-1 / t}\right)$ edges. Later Erdős and Simonovits [9] determined the structure of extremal graphs for $K_{r+1}(t)$ for $t \leqslant 3$ as follows.

Theorem 1. [9] For $t \leqslant 3$, every extremal graph $G$ for $K_{r+1}(t)$ has a vertex partition $U_{1}, \ldots, U_{r}$ such that

- $G\left[U_{i}, U_{j}\right]$ is complete for all $i \neq j$,
- $G\left[U_{i}\right]=n / r+o(n)$,
- $G\left[U_{1}\right]$ is extremal for $K_{t, t}$, and
- $G\left[U_{2}\right], \ldots, G\left[U_{r}\right]$ are extremal for $K_{1, t}$.

The restriction $t \leqslant 3$ in Theorem 1 comes from our knowledge on $\operatorname{ex}\left(n, K_{t, t}\right)$. A well-known open problem in Extremal Graph Theory is proving $\operatorname{ex}\left(n, K_{t, t}\right)=\Omega\left(n^{2-1 / t}\right)$ and this is only known for $t \leqslant 3$.

Extremal problems with multipartite graphs as host graphs have been studied since 1951, when Zarankiewicz proposed the study of the largest number of edges in a $K_{s, t}$-free bipartite graph. Let $\mathcal{G}\left(n_{1}, \ldots, n_{k}\right)$ denote the family of $k$-partite graphs with $n_{1}, \ldots, n_{k}$ vertices in its parts and write $\mathcal{G}_{k}(n)=\mathcal{G}(n, \ldots, n)$ with $k$ parts. Given a graph $F$, define $\operatorname{ex}\left(n_{1}, \ldots, n_{k} ; F\right)$ as the largest number of edges in $F$-free graphs from $\mathcal{G}\left(n_{1}, \ldots, n_{k}\right)$, and let $\operatorname{ex}_{k}(n, F)=\operatorname{ex}(n, \ldots, n ; F)$ (with $k$ parts). (Trivially $\operatorname{ex}_{k}(n, F)=\binom{k}{2} n^{2}$ if the chromatic number $\chi(F)>k$.) In 1975 Bollobás, Erdős, and Szemerédi [2] investigated several Turán-type problem for multipartite graphs. Applying a simple counting argument, they showed that, for any $n, k, r \in \mathbb{N}$ with $k>r$,

$$
\operatorname{ex}_{k}\left(n, K_{r+1}\right)=t_{r}(k) n^{2}
$$

The main results of [2] were on the minimum degree that forces a copy of $K_{r}$ in the graphs of $\mathcal{G}_{k}(n)$. This problem has been intensively studied and resolved when $k=r$ (frequently in its complementary form concerning independent transversals) [13-15,22], and more recently for $k>r$ [17] (certain cases are still unsolved). There are several other extremal results for multipartite graphs. Bollobás, Erdős, and Straus [1] determined $\operatorname{ex}\left(n_{1}, \ldots, n_{r} ; K_{r}\right)$ for all $n_{1}, \ldots, n_{r}$ and $r$. Let $k K_{r}$ denote $k$ vertex-disjoint copies of $K_{r}$. The problem $\operatorname{ex}\left(n_{1}, \ldots, n_{r} ; k K_{r}\right)$ were studied more recently $[6,12,24]$ and settled by Chen, Lu, and Yuan [5] when $n_{1}, \ldots, n_{r}$ are sufficiently large ( $k, r$ are arbitrary but fixed). The minimum pair density of multipartite graphs that forces a clique was studied by Bondy, Shen, Thomassé, and Thomassen [3] and Pfender [19].

In this paper we study $\operatorname{ex}_{k}\left(n, K_{r+1}(t)\right)$, the multi-partite version of the Erdős-Stone theorem and Theorem 1. To give the precise value of $\operatorname{ex}_{k}\left(n, K_{r+1}(t)\right)$, we need the following definition. Given $a, t, n_{1}, \ldots, n_{a} \in \mathbb{N}$, let $z_{t}^{(a)}\left(n_{1}, \ldots, n_{a}\right)$ be the $a$-partite Zarankiewicz number for $K_{t, t}$, that is, the maximum number of edges in a $K_{t, t}$-free bipartite graph with part sizes $n_{1}, \ldots, n_{a}$. For simplicity, we write $z_{t}^{(n)}(n)$ if $n_{1}=\cdots=n_{a}$. We also write $z_{t}(m, n)$ for $z_{t}^{(2)}(m, n)$.

Theorem 1 says that any extremal graph for $K_{r+1}(t)$ is the join of an extremal graph for $K_{t, t}$ and $r-1$ extremal graphs for $K_{1, t}$. Inspired by this, a natural guess of an extremal graph for its $r$-partite analogue is as follows. Suppose $k=a r+b$ with $0 \leqslant b<r$. We start with an $n$-blowup of $T_{r}(k)$, which has $r$ classes and each class has either $a$ or $a+1$ parts. We add a $K_{t, t}$-free graph to one class with the most number of parts and $\left\{K_{1, t}, K_{2,2}\right\}$-free graphs to the remaining $r-1$ classes. If $r<k \leqslant 2 r$, then it is easy to see (as in the proof of Theorem 2) that this graph is $K_{r+1}(t)$-free and has $t_{r}(k) n^{2}+z_{t}(n, n)+(k-r-1)(t-1) n$ edges, and therefore

$$
\operatorname{ex}_{k}\left(n, K_{r+1}(t)\right) \geqslant t_{r}(k) n^{2}+z_{t}(n, n)+(k-r-1)(t-1) n
$$

In this paper we first improve this lower bound when $t \geqslant 2$ and $r<k \leqslant 2 r$.
Theorem 2. Suppose $t \geqslant 2, r<k \leqslant 2 r$ and $n \geqslant 8 t^{2}$. Then $\operatorname{ex}_{k}\left(n, K_{r+1}(t)\right) \geqslant g(n, r, k, t)$, where

$$
g(n, r, k, t):=t_{r}(k) n^{2}+z_{t}(n, n)+(t-1)(k-r-1) n+\min \{k-r-1,2 r-k\}\left\lfloor\frac{(t-1)^{2}}{4}\right\rfloor
$$

The following is our main result, in which we prove a matching upper bound when $t \in\{2,3\}$ and $n$ is sufficiently large.
Theorem 3. For any $t \in\{2,3\}$ and integers $r$, there exists $n_{0}=n_{0}(r) \in \mathbb{N}$ such that for $n \geqslant n_{0}$ and $r<k \leqslant 2 r$, we have $\operatorname{ex}_{k}\left(n, K_{r+1}(t)\right)=g(n, r, k, t)$.

In fact, we conjecture that $\operatorname{ex}_{k}\left(n, K_{r+1}(t)\right)=g(n, r, k, t)$ holds for all $t \geqslant 2, r<k \leqslant 2 r$, and sufficiently large $n$.

A natural question is whether our result can be extended to larger values of $t$ and $k$. For larger value of $t$, although we can use $z_{t}(n, n)$ without knowing its precise value, we need several properties of this function in our proof. Kővári, Sós, Turán [16] showed that $z_{t}(n, n)=O\left(n^{2-1 / t}\right)$ for $t \geqslant 2$ and proving a matching lower bound is a well-known open problem:
$(Z) z_{t}(n, n)=\Omega\left(n^{2-1 / t}\right)$ for $t \geqslant 2$.
It was shown $[4,8]$ that $(Z)$ holds for $t=2,3$. In addition, we will need the following properties.
$(E 1)$ For any $a \in \mathbb{N}$, there exists $\delta>0$ such that for large $n, z_{t}^{(a+1)}(n)-z_{t}^{(a)}(n) \geqslant \delta n^{2-1 / t}$.
$(E 2)$ for any $\varepsilon \in(0,1]$, there exists $\delta>0$ such that for large $n$,

$$
z_{t}(n, n)-z_{t}((1-\varepsilon) n, n) \geqslant \delta n^{2-1 / t}
$$

$(E 3) z_{t}(m, n)-z_{t}(m-1, n) \geqslant t-1$.
We can easily verify $(E 1)-(E 3)$ for $t=2,3$. First, a proof of $(E 1)$ from $(Z)$ for all $t$ is given in Section 3.3. Second, when $t=2,3,(E 2)$ follows from $z_{t}(m, n) \leqslant(1+o(1)) m n^{1-1 / t}$ by Füredi [11] and $z_{t}(n, n) \geqslant(1-o(1)) n^{2-1 / t}$ for $t=2,3$. Third, (E3) holds trivially because adding a vertex with $t-1$ edges to a $K_{t, t}$-free graph will not create a copy of $K_{t, t}$.

We do not know whether similar properties hold when $k>2 r$ : in (E2) we must deal with the $[k / r]$-partite Zarankiewicz number; we also need to replace $t-1$ by $\Omega\left(a^{2} t\right)$ in (E3), which seems out of reach at present.

Theorems 2 and 3 show that our problem is more complex than its non-partite counterpart, Theorem 1. Finally, we show that, when $r$ divides $k$, this additional complexity does not exist, and we give an analogue of Theorem 1, modulo the existence of a set of constantly many exceptional vertices.
Theorem 4. For $r, k \in \mathbb{N}$ with $r \mid k$ and $t=2,3$, there exist $C_{0}, n_{0} \in \mathbb{N}$ such that the following holds for $n \geqslant n_{0}$. Let $G$ be a $K_{r+1}(t)$-free $k$-partite graph with $n$ vertices in each part and $\operatorname{ex}_{k}\left(n, K_{r+1}(t)\right)$ edges. Then there is a vertex partition of $G$ into $U_{1}, \ldots, U_{r}$, each consisting of exactly $k / r$ parts of $G$, and a vertex set $Z \subseteq V(G)$ with $|Z| \leqslant C_{0}$ such that

- $G\left[U_{i} \backslash Z, U_{j} \backslash Z\right]$ is almost complete for all $i \neq j$,
- $G\left[U_{1} \backslash Z\right]$ is $K_{t, t}$-free, and
- $G\left[U_{2} \backslash Z\right], \ldots, G\left[U_{r} \backslash Z\right]$ are $K_{1, t}$-free.

Showing $Z=\varnothing$ in Theorem 4 requires an $a$-partite analogue of (E2), which is unknown for $a \geqslant 3$.
For the rest of this paper we only consider $r \geqslant 2$, as it is easy to see that Theorems 2-4 hold for $r=1$.

Notation. Given integers $n \geqslant m \geqslant 1$, let $[n]=\{1, \ldots, n\}$ and $[m, n]=\{m, m+1, \ldots, n\}$. We omit floors and ceilings unless they are crucial, e.g., we may choose a set of $\varepsilon n$ vertices even if our assumption does not guarantee that $\varepsilon n$ is an integer.

When $X, Y \subseteq V(G)$ intersect, $E_{G}(X, Y)$ is defined as the collection of ordered pairs in $(x, y) \in$ $X \times Y$ such that $\{x, y\} \in E(G)$. Write $e_{G}(X, Y)=\left|E_{G}(X, Y)\right|$. For a vertex $v$ in $G$, let $N(v, X)=$ $N(v) \cap X$ and $d(v, X)=|N(v, X)|$. Moreover, given $X \subseteq V(G)$, let $e(X, G)$ be the number of edges of $G$ incident to the vertices of $X$. Given two graphs $G$ and $H$ on a common vertex set $V, G \cap H$ denotes a graph on $V$ with $E(G \cap H)=E(G) \cap E(H)$. Given a $k$-partition $\left\{V_{1}, V_{2}, \ldots, V_{k}\right\}$, a set $S$ is called crossing if $\left|S \cap V_{i}\right| \leqslant 1, i \in[k]$.

When we choose constants $x, y>0, x \ll y$ means that for any $y>0$ there exists $x_{0}>0$ such that for any $x<x_{0}$ the subsequent statement holds. Hierarchies of other lengths are defined similarly. Furthermore, all constants in the hierarchy are positive and for a constant appearing in the form $1 / s$, we always mean to choose $s$ as an integer.

# 2. Proof of Theorem 2 

In this section we prove Theorem 2, that is, $\exp _{k}\left(n, K_{r+1}(t)\right) \geqslant g(n, r, k, t)$ for $r<k \leqslant 2 r$. Our proof needs a $t$-regular $K_{2,2}$-free bipartite graph with $n$ vertices in each part. It is well known (see [20]) that such graph exists for infinitely many $n \in \mathbb{N}$ with $n \geqslant t^{2}$. The following proposition from [25, Section 2] allows $n$ to be any integer that is at least $8 t^{2}$.

Proposition 2.1. [25] For $t \geqslant 1$ and $n \geqslant 8 t^{2}$, there exists a t-regular $K_{2,2}$-free bipartite graph with $n$ vertices in each part.

Now we prove our lower bound on $\exp _{k}\left(n, K_{r+1}(t)\right)$ stated in Theorem 2.
Proof of Theorem 2. First assume $r<k \leqslant 2 r$ and $t \geqslant 2$. Let $V_{1}, \ldots, V_{k}$ be disjoint sets of size $n$ and, if $k<2 r$, let $V_{k+1}, \ldots, V_{2 r}$ be empty sets. Let $G^{\prime}$ be a complete $r$-partite graph with parts $V_{1} \cup V_{r+1}, V_{2} \cup V_{r+2}, \ldots, V_{r} \cup V_{2 r}$. Moreover, we add to $G^{\prime}$ a maximum $K_{t, t}$-free bipartite graph with bipartition $V_{1} \cup V_{r+1}$, and a $(t-1)$-regular $K_{2,2}$-free bipartite graph on $V_{i} \cup V_{i+r}$ for $2 \leqslant i \leqslant k-r$ (the existence of such graph is guaranteed by Proposition 2.1). The resulting graph is $K_{r+1}(t)$ free because a copy of $K_{r+1}(t)$ has at most $2 t-1$ vertices in $V_{1} \cup V_{r+1}$ and at most $t$ vertices in $V_{i} \cup V_{i+r}$ for $2 \leqslant i \leqslant k-r$. This graph has $t_{r}(k) n^{2}+z_{t}(n)+(t-1)(k-r-1) n$ edges, and thus, $\exp _{k}\left(n, K_{r+1}(t)\right) \geqslant t_{r}(k) n^{2}+z_{t}(n)+(t-1)(k-r-1) n$. This proves the theorem when $t=2$ or $k=2 r$.

Now assume $r<k<2 r$ and $t \geqslant 2$. Let $b=k-r$. Our goal is to give a better construction that shows

$$
\exp _{k}\left(n, K_{r+1}(t)\right) \geqslant t_{r}(k) n^{2}+z_{t}(n, n)+(t-1)(b-1) n+\min \{b-1, r-b\}\left\lfloor\frac{(t-1)^{2}}{4}\right\rfloor
$$

Let $V_{i, j},(i, j) \in[r] \times[2]$ be vertex sets, where $V_{b+1,2}, \ldots, V_{r, 2}$ are empty sets and other sets have size $n$. Let $G=K\left(V_{1,1} \cup V_{1,2}, \ldots, V_{r, 1} \cup V_{r, 2}\right)$ be the complete $r$-partite graph with parts $V_{1,1} \cup$ $V_{1,2}, \ldots, V_{r, 1} \cup V_{r, 2}$. Thus $e(G)=t_{r}(k) n^{2}$.

We first revise the partition as follows. Let $t^{\prime}:=[(t-1) / 2]$ and $b^{\prime}:=\min \{b-1, r-b\}$. Let $\left\{V_{i, j}^{\prime},(i, j) \in[r] \times[2]\right\}$ be obtained from $\bigcup V_{i, j}$ by moving a set $S_{i, 1}$ of $t^{\prime}$ vertices from $V_{i, 1}$ to $V_{i+b-1,1}$, and moving a set $S_{i, 2}$ of $t^{\prime}$ vertices from $V_{i, 2}$ to $V_{i+b-1,2}$, for every $i \in\left[2, b^{\prime}+1\right]$. For $i \in[r]$, let $U_{i}:=V_{i, 1}^{\prime} \cup V_{i, 2}^{\prime}$ and $H:=K\left(U_{1}, \ldots, U_{r}\right) \cap K\left(V_{1,1}, \ldots, V_{r, 1}, V_{1,2}, \ldots, V_{r, 2}\right)$. Let $H^{\prime}$ be obtained from $H$ by adding

- a $K_{t, t}$-free bipartite graph on $U_{1}$ of size $z_{t}(n, n)$, and
- a maximum $\left\{K_{1, t}, K_{2,2}\right\}$-free bipartite graph on $U_{i}$ for $i \in[2, b]$.
- $2 t^{\prime}$ vertex-disjoint copies of $K_{1, t-1}$ on each $U_{i}, i \in\left[b+1, b+b^{\prime}\right]$, where the centers of stars are the $2 t^{\prime}$ vertices of $S_{i-b+1,1} \cup S_{i-b+1,2}$; then add a copy of $K_{t^{\prime}, t^{\prime}}$ on $S_{i-b+1,1} \cup S_{i-b+1,2}$. See Figure 1.
For $i \in[2, b]$, Proposition 2.1 implies that each $H^{\prime}\left[U_{i}\right]$ is $(t-1)$-regular and thus for $i \in\left[2, b^{\prime}+1\right]$, $H^{\prime}\left[U_{i}\right]$ has $\left(n-t^{\prime}\right)(t-1)$ edges, and for $i \in\left[b^{\prime}+2, b\right]$ it has $n(t-1)$ edges; for $i \in\left[b+1, b+b^{\prime}\right]$, each $H^{\prime}\left[U_{i}\right]$ has $2 t^{\prime}(t-1)+\left(t^{\prime}\right)^{2}$ edges. Therefore, the number of edges in $H^{\prime \prime}, H$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& z_{t}(n, n)+\left(n-t^{\prime}\right)(t-1) b^{\prime}+n(t-1)\left(b-b^{\prime}-1\right)+b^{\prime}\left(2 t^{\prime}(t-1)+\left(t^{\prime}\right)^{2}\right) \\
= & z_{t}(n, n)+(t-1)(b-1) n+b^{\prime}\left(t^{\prime}\right)^{2}+b^{\prime} t^{\prime}(t-1) \\
= & z_{t}(n, n)+(t-1)(b-1) n+2 b^{\prime}\left(t^{\prime}\right)^{2}+b^{\prime} t^{\prime}\left(t-1-t^{\prime}\right) \\
= & z_{t}(n, n)+(t-1)(b-1) n+2 b^{\prime}\left(t^{\prime}\right)^{2}+\left\lfloor\frac{(t-1)^{2}}{4}\right\rfloor
\end{aligned}
$$

![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

Figure 1. The lower bound construction for $K_{r+1}(t)$ with $r=5, k=8$ and $t=3$. The left figure is the standard construction similar to the one given in Theorem 1; the right figure is the construction presented in our proof of Theorem 3.

We claim that $H$ contains $t_{r}(k) n^{2}-2 b^{\prime}\left(t^{\prime}\right)^{2}$ edges. Indeed, for every $i \in\left[2, b^{\prime}+1\right]$, the vertices of $S_{i, 1}$ moved from $V_{i, 1}$ to $V_{i+b-1,1}$ lose $n$ edges to $V_{i+b-1,1}$ and gain $n-t^{\prime}$ edges to $V_{i, 2}$, thus having a net loss $\left(t^{\prime}\right)^{2}$ edges between $U_{i}$ and $U_{i+b-1}$; the same holds for $S_{i, 2}$. Thus, our claim holds after summing over all $b^{\prime}$ such rows, which implies that $e\left(H^{\prime}\right)=t_{r}(k) n^{2}+z_{t}(n, n)+(t-1)(b-1) n+b^{\prime}\left[\frac{(t-1)^{2}}{4}\right]$.

At last, we show that $H^{\prime}$ is $K_{r+1}(t)$-free. Recall that by construction, every $U_{i}$ is triangle-free, $U_{1}$ is $K_{t, t}$-free, $U_{2}, \ldots, U_{b}$ are $\left\{K_{1, t}, K_{2,2}\right\}$-free, and each of $U_{b+1}, \ldots, U_{U_{b+b^{\prime}}}$ induces vertex-disjoint copies of $K_{1, t-1}$ whose centers are joined by copies of $K_{t^{\prime}, t^{\prime}}$. Suppose $K$ is a copy of $K_{r+1}(t)$ in $H^{\prime}$. By construction, $K$ contains at most $2 t-1$ vertices in $U_{1}$. We claim that $\left|V(K) \cap\left(U_{i} \cup U_{i+b-1}\right)\right| \leqslant 2 t$ for $i \in\left[2, b^{\prime}+1\right]$ and $\left|V(K) \cap U_{j}\right| \leqslant t$ for $i \in\left[b^{\prime}+2, b\right] \cup\left[b+b^{\prime}+1, r\right]$, which will lead to a contradiction with $|V(K)|=(r+1) t$. Indeed, for $i \in[2, r]$, if $K$ contains at least $t+1$ vertices in $U_{i}$, then these vertices induce either a copy of $K_{1, t}$ or $K_{2,2}$. By construction, this is only possible for $i \in\left[b+1, b+b^{\prime}\right]$ and in that case $V(K) \cap U_{i}$ must intersect both $S_{i-b+1,1}$ and $S_{i-b+1,2}$. Furthermore, there exists $v \in V(K) \cap S_{i-b+1,1}$ and $v^{\prime} \in V(K) \cap S_{i-b+1,2}$ such that $v$ and $v^{\prime}$ are in different color classes of $K$. Since $v$ and $v^{\prime}$ have no common neighbor in $U_{i} \cup U_{i-b+1}, K$ induces at most two classes on $U_{i} \cup U_{i-b+1}$. Thus, $\left|V(K) \cap\left(U_{i} \cup U_{i-b+1}\right)\right| \leqslant 2 t$ and we are done.

Remark. Note that for $t=2$, both our constructions give the same value, which means that the extremal graph is not unique. Indeed, it is easy to see that one can construct $b^{\prime}+1$ different ones as we can move vertices for a subset of the $b^{\prime}$ rows.

# 3. Stability and proof outline 

Let us first consider extremal graph for $\exp _{k}\left(n, K_{r+1}\right)$. Given $r, k \in \mathbb{N}$ with $k>r$, write $k=a r+b$ for $0 \leqslant b \leqslant r-1$. By Turán's theorem, the Turán graph $T_{r}(k):=K_{a, \ldots, a, a+1, \ldots, a+1}$ (with $b$ parts of size $a+1$ and $r-b$ parts of size $a$ ) is the unique largest $K_{r+1}$-free graph on $k$ vertices. The following definition shows that there are many extremal graphs for $\exp _{k}\left(n, K_{r+1}\right)$.
Definition 3.1. Let $\mathcal{T}_{r, k}(n)$ be the collection of $k$-partite graphs with parts $V_{1}, \ldots, V_{k}$ of size $n$ defined as follows. If $b>0$, we arbitrarily divide $V_{a r+1}, \ldots, V_{k}$ into $r$ sets $W_{1}, \ldots, W_{r}$ (some of them may be empty) such that each $W_{i}$ is a subset of $V_{j}$ for some $j$; if $b=0$, then let $W_{1}, \ldots, W_{r}$ be empty sets. Now let $T$ be the $r$-partite graph with parts $U_{1}, \ldots, U_{r}$ such that

$$
U_{i}=W_{i} \cup Z_{i}, \text { where } Z_{i}:=V_{(i-1) a+1} \cup \cdots \cup V_{i a}
$$

obtained from the complete $r$-partite graph $K\left(U_{1}, \ldots, U_{r}\right)$ by removing edges between $W_{i}$ and $W_{i^{\prime}}$, $i \neq i^{\prime}$, whenever $W_{i}, W_{i^{\prime}} \subseteq V_{j}$ for some $j$ (in other words, $T=K\left(U_{1}, \ldots, U_{r}\right) \cap K\left(V_{1}, \ldots, V_{k}\right)$ ).

Since $T$ is $r$-partite, it is $K_{r+1}$-free. Let $U=\bigcup_{i \in[r]} U_{i}$ and $W=\bigcup_{i \in[r]} W_{i}$. Note that $e_{T}(U)=$ $\binom{r}{2} a^{2} n^{2}$ while the number of edges of $T$ incident to $W$ is equal to $|W|(k-a-1) n=b(k-a-1) n^{2}$. Since $t_{r}(k)=\binom{r}{2} a^{2}+b(k-a-1)$, it follows that $e(T)=t_{r}(k) n^{2}$. By (1.1), $T$ is an extremal graph for $K_{r+1} \cdot{ }^{1}$
3.1. A stability theorem. We need the following stability result for $\operatorname{ex}_{k}\left(n, K_{r+1}(t)\right)$. Given two graphs $G, H \in \mathcal{G}_{k}(n)$ on the same parts $V_{1}, \ldots, V_{k}$, we say that $G$ and $H$ are $\gamma$-close if $|E(G) \triangle E(H)| \leqslant \gamma n^{2}$.
Theorem 5. For any $k, r, t \in \mathbb{N}$ and any $\gamma>0$, there exist $\varepsilon>0$ and $n_{0} \in \mathbb{N}$ such that the following holds for every integer $n \geqslant n_{0}$. Suppose $G \in \mathcal{G}_{k}(n)$ is $K_{r+1}(t)$-free and $e(G) \geqslant\left(t_{r}(k)-\varepsilon\right) n^{2}$. Then $G$ is $\gamma$-close to a member of $\mathcal{T}_{r, k}(n)$. In particular, we have $e(G) \leqslant\left(t_{r}(k)+\gamma\right) n^{2}$.

In the earlier version of this paper, we gave a self-contained proof of Theorems 5. Here we derive it from a stronger result of Chen, Lu and Yuan [5, Theorem 1.5], in which they provide more structural information. Their definition and result are more general by allowing the parts $V_{i}$ of $G$ to have different sizes. Here we only state their definition and result that we need for the balanced case.
Definition 3.2 (Stable partition). Let $k \geqslant r \geqslant 2$ be integers. Let $\mathcal{P}=\left\{P_{1}, \ldots, P_{r}\right\}$ and $\mathcal{V}=$ $\left\{V_{1}, \ldots, V_{k}\right\}$ where $\left|V_{i}\right|=n$ for all $i \in[k]$ be partitions of a common vertex set. For $i \in[r], j \in[k]$, a set $W=P_{i} \cap V_{j}$ is called an integral part if $W=V_{j}$, and called a partial part otherwise. We say that $\mathcal{P}$ is stable to $\mathcal{V}$, if each of $P_{1}, \ldots, P_{r}$ has the same number of integral parts and at most one partial part.
Definition 3.3 ( $(X, \varepsilon)$-stable). Let $n, r, k$ be integers with $n \geqslant k \geqslant r \geqslant 2$. For a given spanning subgraph $G$ of $K_{k}(n)$, let $\mathcal{P}=\left\{P_{1}, \ldots, P_{r}\right\}$ be a partition of $V(G)$ and $\mathcal{V}=\left\{V_{1}, \ldots, V_{k}\right\}$ be the natural $k$-partition. Given $\varepsilon \in(0,1)$ and a set $X \subseteq V(G)$ of size at most $\varepsilon n$, we say that $\mathcal{P}$ is an $(X, \varepsilon)$-stable partition if

- $G-X$ is $\varepsilon$-close to $K\left(P_{1}, \ldots, P_{r}\right)-X$
- $\left\{P_{1} \backslash X, \ldots, P_{r} \backslash X\right\}$ is stable to $\left\{V_{1} \backslash X, \ldots, V_{k} \backslash X\right\}$.

Theorem 6. [5, Theorem 1.5] Let $F$ be a graph with chromatic number $r+1 \geqslant 3$. For every $\varepsilon>0$ there exists $\delta>0$ and integer $n_{0}>0$ such that the following holds for $n \geqslant n_{0}$. Let $G$ be an $F$-free subgraph of $K_{k}(n)$ with $k>r$ such that $e(G) \geqslant \operatorname{ex}_{k}(n, F)-\delta n^{2}$. Then, $G$ has an $(X, \varepsilon)$-stable partition $\left\{P_{1}, \ldots, P_{t-1}\right\}$ for some set $X \subseteq V(G)$ of size at most $\varepsilon n$.

Now Theorem 5 follows from Theorem 6 by setting $F=K_{r+1}(t)$ and noticing that i) a partition is stable if and only if it is a partition required in Definition 3.1 and ii) as $|X| \leqslant \varepsilon n, X$ is incident to at most $\varepsilon n^{2}$ edges that we have no control on.

We remark that although Theorem 6 is stronger, the additional structural information is not immediately useful to us. For example, the set $X$ introduced in Theorem 6 is the set of atypical vertices of $G$ (see also the proof outline in next section). However, we need a stronger control and indeed we need to distinguish two kinds of atypical vertices. Identifying them from $X$ is almost equivalent to identifying them from $V(G)$. So we choose to present and use the easier and more classical version, Theorem 5, in this paper.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{1}$ Indeed, Chen, Lu, and Yuan [5] showed that $\mathcal{T}_{r, k}(n)$ are all the extremal graphs for $\operatorname{ex}_{k}\left(n, K_{r+1}\right)$ and described all extremal graphs for $\operatorname{ex}\left(n_{1}, \ldots, n_{k} ; K_{r+1}\right)$.

3.2. Outline of the proofs. Now we give an outline of our proofs. Let $G \in \mathcal{G}_{k}(n)$ be $K_{r+1}(t)$-free and has the maximum number of edges. Since $e(G)>t_{r}(k) n^{2}$, we can assume that $G$ is $\gamma$-close to some $T \in \mathcal{T}_{r, k}(n)$. Since $e(G)$ is maximum, we can easily derive a minimum degree condition by symmetrization arguments.

Next we define atypical vertices. Roughly speaking, there are two types of atypical vertices: the first type of vertices, denoted by $Z^{\prime \prime} \cup W^{\prime \prime}$, are the "wrong" ones that do not exist in $\mathcal{T}_{r, k}(n)$; the second type of vertices, denoted by $\left(W_{i}^{\prime} \backslash W_{i}\right) \cup \bigcup_{j \neq i} Z_{j}^{\prime}$ for $i \in[r]$, are the vertices that are not in $U_{i}$ but behave like the vertices of $U_{i}$, in other words, they are in the wrong place. We temporarily ignore the first type of atypical vertices because there are only a constant number of them (see $(P 1)$ and $(P 3))$ and they contribute only $O(n)$ to $e(G)$. For the second type of atypical vertices, there are only $o(n)$ of them (see $(P 1)$ and $(P 3)$ ) and we move them to appropriate rows and redefine our partition as $\tilde{U}_{1}, \ldots, \tilde{U}_{r}$ (see (4.2)). A key observation is that $Z_{j}^{\prime} \neq \varnothing$ (namely, there is a vertex in $Z_{j}$ but behaves as a vertex in $Z_{i}$ ) only if $\left|W_{j}\right| \geqslant(1-o(1)) n$.

Now we estimate $e(G)$. We split $E(G)$ into $E_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{1}\right), \ldots, E_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{r}\right)$, and $E\left(G^{\prime}\right)$, where $G^{\prime}:=G \cap$ $K\left(\tilde{U}_{1}, \ldots, \tilde{U}_{r}\right)$. We have a relatively good estimate of $e\left(G^{\prime}\right)$ (see Claim 4.3) taking into account that the partition is no longer balanced. In contrast, due to the second type of atypical vertices, we can only show that each $G\left[\tilde{U}_{i}\right]$ is "almost" $K_{t, t}$-free (see Claim 4.4). Similarly, we show that all but at most one rows are "almost" $K_{1, t}$-free (see Claim 4.6). Assuming that $e_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{1}\right)$ is the largest among all $e_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{i}\right), i \in[r]$, we can use these properties and give an upper bound of $e(G)$. Next we show that $\tilde{U}_{1}$ has no atypical vertices (Claim 4.8), and thus $e_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{1}\right) \leqslant z_{t}^{(a+1)}(n)$. We further refine our estimate on $\tilde{U}_{i}, i>1$, and show that each second type atypical vertex contributes at most a constant number of edges to $E(G) \backslash E\left(G^{\prime}\right)$ (Claim 4.9). In summary, $\tilde{U}_{1}$ is indeed $K_{t, t}$-free, $e_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{i}\right)=O(n)$ for $i>1$, and $\left|Z^{\prime \prime} \cup W^{\prime \prime}\right|=O(1)$, from which we conclude the proof of Theorem 4.

To prove Theorem 3, we refine earlier estimates as follows. We first show that $\left|W_{1}^{\prime}\right|=(1-o(1)) n$ and $Z^{\prime \prime} \cup W^{\prime \prime}=\varnothing$, where we use $(E 2)$. The rest of the proofs are further refinements of our estimates. In particular, we show that if $\left|W_{i}^{\prime}\right|$ is not too small, then $\tilde{U}_{i}$ essentially contains no vertex from other rows.

# 3.3. Two quick proofs. We first derive $(E 1)$ from $(Z)$. 

Proof of $(Z) \Rightarrow(E 1)$. Given $a+1$ sets $V_{1}, \ldots, V_{a+1}$ of size $n$, we define an $(a+1)$-partite graph $G$ on $V_{1}, \ldots, V_{a+1}$ as follows. Let $V_{2}^{\prime}$ be a set of $n$ vertices consisting of $[n / 2]$ vertices from $V_{1}$ and $[n / 2]$ vertices from $V_{2}$. We place an extremal graph $G^{\prime}$ for $z_{t}^{(a)}(n)$ on $V_{2}^{\prime}, V_{3}, \ldots, V_{a+1}$, in other words, $G^{\prime}$ is an $a$-partite $K_{t, t}$-free graph with $z_{t}^{(a)}(n)$ edges. Next we add a maximum bipartite $K_{t, t}$-free graph $G^{\prime \prime}$ on the remaining vertices of $V_{1}$ and $V_{2}$. By $(Z), e\left(G^{\prime \prime}\right) \geqslant z_{t}^{(2)}(\{n / 2\}) \geqslant \delta n^{2-1 / t}$ for some $\delta>0$. Thus $G=G^{\prime} \cup G^{\prime \prime}$ is $K_{t, t}$-free and $e(G)=e\left(G^{\prime}\right)+e\left(G^{\prime \prime}\right) \geqslant z_{t}^{(a)}(n)+\delta n^{2-1 / t}$. This gives $(E 1)$.

We need the following simple proposition.
Proposition 3.4. Given $r, t \in \mathbb{N}$ and reals $\gamma, \varepsilon>0$ such that $\varepsilon^{2}>3 r^{2} t^{2} \gamma$, and let $n$ be sufficiently large. Suppose $G$ is a $K_{r+1}(t)$-free graph with vertex partition $V=U_{1} \cup \cdots \cup U_{r}$ such that $\left|U_{i}\right| \geqslant n$ for $i \in[r]$ and $d\left(U_{i}, U_{j}\right) \geqslant 1-\gamma, i, j \in[r], i \neq j$. Let $X \subseteq V$ be the set of vertices $v$ satisfies that $d\left(v, U_{i}\right) \geqslant \varepsilon\left|U_{i}\right|$ for all $i \in[r]$. Then $|X| \leqslant 2(t-1) \varepsilon^{-r t}$.

Proof. We call a copy of $K_{r}(t)$ in $G$ useful if it consists of exactly $t$ vertices from each of $U_{1}, \ldots, U_{r}$. We first show that for every $v \in X, N(v)$ contains many useful copies of $K_{r}(t)$. Indeed, $d\left(U_{i}, U_{j}\right) \geqslant$ $1-\gamma$ for every $i, j \in[r], i \neq j$ implies that $G\left[U_{i}, U_{j}\right]$ has at most $\gamma\left|U_{i}\right|\left|U_{j}\right|$ non-edges. Since

$d\left(v, U_{i}\right) \geqslant \varepsilon\left|U_{i}\right|$ for all $i \in[r]$, take $W_{i} \subseteq N(v) \cap U_{i}$ of size exactly $\varepsilon\left|U_{i}\right|$. We can find $\prod_{i \in[r]}\binom{\varepsilon\left|U_{i}\right|}{t}$ $r t$-sets which consists of $t$ vertices from each $U_{i}$, amongst which, at most

$$
\sum_{i, j \in[r], i \neq j} \gamma\left|U_{i}\right|\left|U_{j}\right| \cdot\left(\prod_{i^{\prime} \in[r]}\binom{\varepsilon\left|U_{i^{\prime}}\right|}{t}\right) \cdot \frac{t}{\varepsilon\left|U_{i}\right|} \frac{t}{\varepsilon\left|U_{j}\right|} \leqslant \frac{r^{2} t^{2} \gamma}{\varepsilon^{2}} \prod_{i^{\prime} \in[r]}\binom{\varepsilon\left|U_{i^{\prime}}\right|}{t}
$$

of them contain crossing non-edges. Therefore, $N(v)$ contains at least

$$
\left(1-\frac{r^{2} t^{2} \gamma}{\varepsilon^{2}}\right) \prod_{i^{\prime} \in[r]}\binom{\varepsilon\left|U_{i^{\prime}}\right|}{t} \geqslant \frac{\varepsilon^{r t}}{2} \prod_{i^{\prime} \in[r]}\binom{\left|U_{i^{\prime}}\right|}{t}
$$

useful copies of $K_{r}(t)$, where we used that $r^{2} t^{2} \gamma \varepsilon^{-2}<1 / 3$. Since $G$ is $K_{r+1}(t)$-free, each useful copy $K$ of $K_{r}(t)$ is in $N(v)$ for at most $t-1$ choices of $v \in X$. Double counting on the number of pairs $(v, K)$ such that $K \subseteq N(v)$ is useful, we obtain that

$$
|X| \frac{\varepsilon^{r t}}{2} \prod_{i^{\prime} \in[r]}\binom{\left|U_{i^{\prime}}\right|}{t} \leqslant(t-1) \prod_{i^{\prime} \in[r]}\binom{\left|U_{i^{\prime}}\right|}{t}
$$

which gives $|X| \leqslant 2(t-1) \varepsilon^{-r t}$.

# 4. Main Proofs 

Given integers $1 \leqslant s \leqslant t$ and sufficiently large $m, n$, Kővári, Sós, Turán [16] showed that $z(m, n, s, t) \leqslant C m n^{1-1 / s}$ for some $C=C(t)>0$, that is, a bipartite graph $G$ with parts of size $m$ and $n$ has at most $C m n^{1-1 / s}$ edges if $G$ has no copy of $K_{s, t}$ where the part of size $s$ is in the part of $G$ of size $m$. We start the proof with the general setting, that is, for $k=a r+b$ with $0 \leqslant b<r$. After we conclude the proof of Theorem 4, we focus on the case $k \leqslant 2 r$.

Proofs of Theorems 3 and 4. Suppose $t=2,3$ and thus $(Z)$ holds, that is, $z_{t}^{(2)}(n) \geqslant c n^{2-1 / t}$ for some $c>0$. Take $C=C(t)$ as in the Kővári-Sós-Turán result in the previous paragraph. We choose constants

$$
1 / n \ll \gamma \ll \varepsilon \ll \varepsilon^{\prime} \ll 1 / k, 1 / t, c, C
$$

Suppose $G$ is $K_{r+1}(t)$-free and has the maximum number of edges, that is, $e(G)=\exp _{k}\left(n, K_{r+1}(t)\right)$. Suppose further that $e(G)>g(n, r, k, t)>t_{r}(k) n^{2}$. By Theorem $5, G$ is $\gamma$-close to some $T \in \mathcal{T}_{r, k}(n)$ such that $T=K\left(U_{1}, \ldots, U_{r}\right) \cap K\left(V_{1}, \ldots, V_{k}\right)$, where $U_{1}, \ldots, U_{r}$ is a partition of $V(T)$ satisfying the following properties:

- $U_{i}=W_{i} \cup Z_{i}$ such that $Z_{i}=V_{(i-1) a+1} \cup \cdots \cup V_{i a}$, and
- $W_{i}=\varnothing$ if $b=0$ and $W_{i}$ is a subset of $V_{q_{i}}$ for some $q_{i}$ with $a r<q_{i} \leqslant k$ otherwise.

For simplicity, we write $z_{t}(n)=z_{t}^{([k / r]}(n)$.
The fact that $G$ is $\gamma$-close to $T$ gives the following observation.
(D0) for any $i \in[r]$, there exists $B_{i} \subseteq U_{i}$ of size at most $2 \sqrt{\gamma} n$ such that for any $v \in U_{i} \backslash B_{i}$ and $A \subseteq \bigcup_{j \in[r] \backslash\{i\}} U_{j}$ satisfying that none of the vertices of $A$ is in the same cluster as $v$ is, we have $\bar{d}(v, A) \leqslant \sqrt{\gamma} n$.
To see it, fix $i \in[r]$ and write $U^{*}:=\bigcup_{j \neq i} U_{j}$. Since $G$ is $\gamma$-close to $T$, we have

$$
e_{G}\left(Z_{i}, U^{*}\right) \geqslant\left|Z_{i}\right|\left|U^{*}\right|-\gamma n^{2}, \quad \text { and } \quad e_{G}\left(W_{i}, U^{*} \backslash V_{q_{i}}\right) \geqslant\left|W_{i}\right|\left|U^{*} \backslash V_{q_{i}}\right|-\gamma n^{2}
$$

Let $B_{i}^{\prime} \subseteq Z_{i}$ be the set of vertices $v$ such that $\bar{d}\left(v, U^{*}\right)>\sqrt{\gamma} n$, and $B_{i}^{\prime \prime} \subseteq W_{i}$ be the set of vertices $w$ such that $\bar{d}\left(w, U^{*} \backslash V_{q_{i}}\right)>\sqrt{\gamma} n$. The displayed line above implies that $\left|B_{i}^{\prime}\right| \leqslant \sqrt{\gamma} n$ and $\left|B_{i}^{\prime \prime}\right| \leqslant \sqrt{\gamma} n$. Now (D0) holds by setting $B_{i}=B_{i}^{\prime} \cup B_{i}^{\prime \prime}$.

Minimum degree. For $i \in[k]$, let $N_{i}:=N_{T}\left(u_{i}\right)$ for some $u_{i} \in V_{i}$. Note that this is well-defined as the vertices of $V_{i}$ share the same neighborhood in $T$. Using the maximality of $e(G)$, we derive that for every $u \in V_{i}, i \in[k]$

$$
d_{G}(u) \geqslant d_{T}(u)-2 t \gamma n
$$

Indeed, since $G$ is $\gamma$-close to $T$, that is, $|E(G) \triangle E(T)| \leqslant \gamma n^{2}$, for each $i \in[k]$, we can greedily pick distinct $u_{1}, \ldots, u_{t} \in V_{i}$, such that $\left|N_{G}\left(u_{j}\right) \triangle N_{i}\right| \leqslant \gamma n^{2} /(n-j) \leqslant 2 \gamma n$, for $j \in[t]$. Let $N_{i}^{\prime}:=\bigcap_{j \in[t]} N_{G}\left(u_{j}\right)$ and note that $\left|N_{i}^{\prime} \triangle N_{i}\right| \leqslant 2 t \gamma n$. In particular, $\left|N_{i}^{\prime}\right| \geqslant\left|N_{i}\right|-2 t \gamma n$. Now for a contradiction suppose there is $u \in V_{i}$ such that $d_{G}(u)<d_{T}(u)-2 t \gamma n=\left|N_{i}\right|-2 t \gamma n$. Then we replace $N_{G}(u)$ by $N_{i}^{\prime}$, that is, we disconnect all the edges of $u$ in $G$ and connect $u$ to the vertices of $N_{i}^{\prime}$. Thus, we obtain a $k$-partite graph on the same vertex set as $G$ and has more edges than $G$. Therefore, by the maximality of $G$, this new graph contains a copy of $K_{r+1}(t)$, denoted by $K$. Clearly, $K$ must contain the vertex $u$, as $G$ is $K_{r+1}(t)$-free. Moreover, $K$ must miss at least one vertex from $u_{1}, \ldots, u_{t}$, say $u_{j}$, because the set $\left\{u, u_{1}, \ldots, u_{t}\right\}$ is independent in $G$ and $K$ has independence number $t$. However, as the neighborhood of $u N_{i}^{\prime}$ is a subset of $N_{G}\left(u_{j}\right)$, we can replace $u$ by $u_{j}$ and still get a copy of $K_{r+1}(t)$, which is in $G$, a contradiction.

Therefore, comparing with the degrees in $T$, we derive that for any vertex $u$,

$$
d_{G}(u) \geqslant \begin{cases}(k-a) n-\left|W_{i}\right|-2 t \gamma n, & \text { if } u \in Z_{i} \text { for } i \in[r] \\ (k-1-a) n-2 t \gamma n, & \text { if } u \in W\end{cases}
$$

Atypical vertices. In this step we identify a set of atypical vertices, that is, those behave differently from the majority of the vertices. Let $W:=\bigcup_{i \in[r]} W_{i}=V_{a r+1} \cup \cdots \cup V_{k}$. We define $W^{\prime \prime}:=$ $\left\{v \in W: d\left(v, Z_{j}\right) \geqslant \varepsilon n\right.$, for all $\left.j \in[r]\right\}$ and $W_{i}^{\prime}:=\left\{v \in W: d\left(v, Z_{i}\right)<\varepsilon n\right\}$. Then we have $W=W^{\prime \prime} \cup W_{1}^{\prime} \cup \cdots \cup W_{r}^{\prime}$. Next, for $i \in[r]$, let $Z^{\prime \prime}:=\bigcup_{i \in[r]} Z_{i}^{\prime \prime}$, where

$$
Z_{i}^{\prime \prime}:=\left\{v \in Z_{i}: d\left(v, Z_{j}\right) \geqslant \varepsilon n, \text { for all } j \in[r] \backslash\{i\} \quad \text { and } \quad d\left(v, U_{i}\right) \geqslant \varepsilon n\right\}
$$

Furthermore, let $Z_{i}^{\prime}:=Z_{i} \backslash Z_{i}^{\prime \prime}$ and write $Z_{i}^{\prime}$ as $\bigcup_{j \in[r]} Z_{i}^{j}$, where $Z_{i}^{j}, j \neq i$, consists of the vertices $v \in Z_{i}$ such that $d\left(v, Z_{j}\right)<\varepsilon n$, and $Z_{i}^{i}$ consists of the vertices $v$ such that $d\left(v, U_{i}\right)<\varepsilon n$. The following are some useful properties of these sets.

Claim 4.1. The following properties hold for all $i \in[r]$.
$(P 1)\left|W_{i}^{\prime} \backslash W_{i}\right| \leqslant 2 \gamma n$ and $\left|W^{\prime \prime}\right| \leqslant C_{0}:=2 t \varepsilon^{-r t}$.
$(P 2) W=W^{\prime \prime} \cup W_{1}^{\prime} \cup \cdots \cup W_{r}^{\prime}$ is a partition of $W$.
$(P 3)\left|Z_{i}^{\prime \prime}\right| \leqslant C_{0},\left|Z_{i}^{j}\right| \leqslant \sqrt{\gamma} n$ for $j \neq i$, and $\left|Z_{i}^{i}\right| \geqslant(1-\sqrt{\gamma}) a n$.
$(P 4) \bigcup_{j \in[r]} Z_{i}^{j}$ is a partition of $Z_{i}^{\prime}$.
Proof. Recall the definition of $W^{\prime \prime}$ and that $d\left(Z_{i}, Z_{j}\right) \geqslant 1-\gamma$ for distinct $i, j \in[r]$. Applying Proposition 3.4 to the graph $G\left[W^{\prime \prime} \cup Z\right]$ with vertex partition $\left(U_{1}, \ldots, U_{r}\right)$, we obtain that $\left|W^{\prime \prime}\right| \leqslant$ $C_{0}:=2 t \varepsilon^{-r t}$. We next show that $\left|W_{i}^{\prime \prime} \backslash W_{i}\right| \leqslant 2 \gamma n$ for each $i \in[r]$. Indeed, because $G$ is $\gamma$-close to $T$, we have $e_{G}\left(Z_{i}, W_{i}^{\prime \prime} \backslash W_{i}\right) \geqslant a n\left|W_{i}^{\prime \prime} \backslash W_{i}\right|-\gamma n^{2}$. On the other hand, by definition, $e_{G}\left(Z_{i}, W_{i}^{\prime \prime} \backslash W_{i}\right)<$ $\left|W_{i}^{\prime \prime} \backslash W_{i}\right| \cdot \varepsilon n$. Thus, we get $\left|W_{i}^{\prime \prime} \backslash W_{i}\right|<\gamma n /(a-\varepsilon)<2 \gamma n$, verifying ( $P 1$ ).

To see $(P 2)$, suppose there is a vertex $v \in W_{i}^{\prime} \cap W_{j}^{\prime}$. By definition, $d(v) \leqslant(k-1) n-2(a-\varepsilon) n<$ $(k-1-a) n-\sqrt{\gamma} n$, contradicting (4.1).

Next we show (P3). Fix $i \in[r]$. Since $G$ is $\gamma$-close to $T$, we have $d\left(Z_{j}, Z_{j^{\prime}}\right) \geqslant 1-\gamma$ and $d\left(U_{i}, Z_{j}\right) \geqslant 1-\gamma$ for distinct $j, j^{\prime} \in[r] \backslash\{i\}$. Thus, we can apply Proposition 3.4 on $G\left[U_{i} \cup \bigcup_{j \neq i} Z_{j}\right]$ (with the obvious $r$-partition) and obtain $\left|Z_{i}^{\prime \prime}\right| \leqslant C_{0}$. Moreover, for $i \neq j$, from $d\left(Z_{i}, Z_{j}\right) \geqslant 1-\gamma$ we infer $\left|Z_{i}^{j}\right| \leqslant(\gamma / \varepsilon) n \leqslant \sqrt{\gamma} n$, as $\gamma \ll \varepsilon$. Therefore, we also get $\left|Z_{i}^{i}\right| \geqslant\left|Z_{i}\right|-\left|Z_{i}^{\prime \prime}\right|-\sum_{j \neq i}\left|Z_{i}^{j}\right| \geqslant$ $a n-C_{0}-(r-1) \gamma n / \varepsilon \geqslant(1-\sqrt{\gamma}) a n$.

Now we show (P4). By definition, if $v \in Z_{i}^{\prime}$, then $d\left(v, U_{i}\right)<\varepsilon n$; if $v \in Z_{i}^{j}$ for $j \neq i$, then $d\left(v, Z_{j}\right)<\varepsilon n$. Thus, we have $Z_{i}^{\prime} \subseteq \bigcup_{j \in[r]} Z_{i}^{j}$ by definition. A vertex $v \in Z_{i}^{\prime} \cap Z_{i}^{j}, j \neq i$, satisfies that $d(v)<k n-\left(\left|U_{i}\right|-\varepsilon n\right)-(a-\varepsilon) n \leqslant(k-a) n-\left|W_{i}\right|-(1-2 \varepsilon) n$, contradicting (4.1). A vertex $v \in Z_{i}^{j} \cap Z_{i}^{j^{\prime}}$ for distinct $j, j^{\prime} \in[r] \backslash\{i\}$ satisfies that $d(v)<(k-1) n-2(a-\varepsilon) n \leqslant(k-a-2) n+2 \varepsilon n$, contradicting (4.1) as well. Thus, $\bigcup_{j \in[r]} Z_{i}^{j}$ is a partition of $Z_{i}^{\prime}$.

For $i \in[r]$, our refined partition is defined by

$$
\tilde{U}_{i}:=\tilde{Z}_{i} \cup W_{i}^{\prime}, \text { where } \tilde{Z}_{i}:=\bigcup_{j \in[r]} Z_{j}^{i}
$$

Then $V(G)=Z^{\prime \prime} \cup W^{\prime \prime} \cup \bigcup_{i \in[r]} \tilde{U}_{i}$. Note that for any $v \in \tilde{U}_{i}$, we have $d\left(v, Z_{i}^{i}\right) \leqslant d\left(v, Z_{i}\right) \leqslant \varepsilon n$, and thus $d\left(v, \tilde{Z}_{i}\right) \leqslant \varepsilon n+(r-1) \sqrt{\gamma} n$ by $(P 3)$.

For every $i \in[r]$, note that $(P 1)$ implies that $\left|W_{i} \backslash W_{i}^{\prime}\right| \leqslant C_{0}+(r-1) 2 \gamma n \leqslant 2 r \gamma n$, and similarly ( $P 3$ ) implies that $\left|Z_{i} \backslash \tilde{Z}_{i}\right| \leqslant C_{0}+(r-1) \sqrt{\gamma} n \leqslant r \sqrt{\gamma} n$.

We now derive a more handy minimum degree condition. For convenience, define $\bar{d}(v, A)=$ $|A|-d(v, A)$. For $v \in Z_{i}^{\prime}$, we have $\bar{d}\left(v, \tilde{U}_{i}\right) \geqslant \bar{d}\left(v, U_{i}\right)-\left|U_{i} \backslash \tilde{U}_{i}\right|$. Since $\bar{d}\left(v, U_{i}\right)>a n+\left|W_{i}\right|-\varepsilon n$ and $\left|U_{i} \backslash \tilde{U}_{i}\right| \leqslant\left|Z_{i} \backslash \tilde{Z}_{i}\right|+\left|W_{i} \backslash W_{i}^{\prime}\right| \leqslant \varepsilon n / 2$, we have $\bar{d}\left(v, \tilde{U}_{i}\right) \geqslant a n+\left|W_{i}\right|-\varepsilon n-\varepsilon n / 2$. By (4.1), $\bar{d}(v) \leqslant a n+\left|W_{i}\right|+\sqrt{\gamma} n$. It follows that $\bar{d}\left(v, V \backslash \tilde{U}_{i}\right) \leqslant 2 \varepsilon n$. Now consider $v \in \tilde{U}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}^{\prime}$. The definition of $\tilde{U}_{i}$ implies that $d\left(v, Z_{i}\right)<\varepsilon n$ and $\bar{d}\left(v, Z_{i}\right)>a n-\varepsilon n$. Assume $v \in V_{j}$. Then $V_{j} \cap Z_{i}=\varnothing$ and trivially $\bar{d}\left(v, V_{j}\right)=n$. It follows that $\bar{d}\left(v, Z_{i} \cup V_{j}\right)>(a+1) n-\varepsilon n$. Hence $\bar{d}\left(v, \tilde{Z}_{i} \cup V_{j}\right) \geqslant$ $\bar{d}\left(v, Z_{i} \cup V_{j}\right)-\left|Z_{i} \backslash \tilde{Z}_{i}\right|>(a+1) n-\frac{3}{2} \varepsilon n$. On the other hand, either case of (4.1) implies that $\bar{d}(v) \leqslant(a+1) n+\sqrt{\gamma} n$. Consequently, $\bar{d}\left(v, V \backslash\left(\tilde{Z}_{i} \cup V_{j}\right)\right) \leqslant 2 \varepsilon n$. In summary, for $i \in[r]$ and $j \in[k]$,
(Deg) If $v \in Z_{i}^{\prime}$, then $\bar{d}\left(v, V \backslash \tilde{U}_{i}\right) \leqslant 2 \varepsilon n$; if $v \in\left(\tilde{U}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}^{\prime}\right) \cap V_{j}$, then $\bar{d}\left(v, V \backslash\left(\tilde{Z}_{i} \cup V_{j}\right)\right) \leqslant 2 \varepsilon n$.
Next we prove further properties on $Z_{i}^{j}$ and $\tilde{Z}_{j}$.
Claim 4.2. If $Z_{i}^{j} \neq \varnothing$ for some $i \neq j$, then the following holds.
(Q1) For $v \in Z_{i}^{j}$ and $A \subseteq V(G) \backslash\left(Z_{i} \cup Z_{j}\right)$, we have $d(v, A) \geqslant|A|-\varepsilon n-\sqrt{\gamma} n$.
(Q2) $\left|W_{i}\right| \geqslant(1-\varepsilon-\sqrt{\gamma}) n$.
(Q3) If $\left|\tilde{Z}_{j} \backslash Z_{j}\right| \geqslant t$, then $\left|W_{j}\right| \leqslant 2 t \varepsilon n$.
Proof. Note that $d\left(v, Z_{j}\right) \leqslant \varepsilon n$ and $d\left(v, Z_{i}\right) \leqslant(a-1) n$, that is, $v$ has at least $n+(a n-\varepsilon n)=$ $(a+1) n-\varepsilon n$ non-neighbors in $Z_{i} \cup Z_{j}$. On the other hand, (4.1) says that $v$ has at most $a n+\left|W_{i}\right|+\sqrt{\gamma} n$ non-neighbors in $G$. Combining these two we get that $v$ has at most $\left|W_{i}\right|-n+\varepsilon n+\sqrt{\gamma} n \leqslant \varepsilon n+\sqrt{\gamma} n$ non-neighbors outside $Z_{i} \cup Z_{j}$, and thus (Q1) holds. The fact that $\left|W_{i}\right|-n+\varepsilon n+\sqrt{\gamma} n \geqslant 0$ implies $(Q 2)$.

For (Q3), suppose to the contrary, $\left|\tilde{Z}_{j} \backslash Z_{j}\right| \geqslant t$ and $\left|W_{j}\right|>2 t \varepsilon n$. By (Q1) with $A=W_{j}$, arbitrary $t$ vertices in $\tilde{Z}_{j} \backslash Z_{j}$ have at least $\left|W_{j}\right|-t(\varepsilon+\sqrt{\gamma}) n \geqslant t$ common neighbors in $W_{j}$. We thus obtain a copy of $K_{t, i}$ with one part in $\tilde{Z}_{j} \backslash Z_{j}$ and the other part in $W_{j}$ - denote its vertex set by $B$. For any $i^{\prime} \in[r] \backslash\{j\}$ such that $B \cap Z_{i^{\prime}}^{j} \neq \varnothing$, we have $\left|W_{i^{\prime}}\right| \geqslant(1-\varepsilon-\sqrt{\gamma}) n$ by (Q2). Since $\left|W_{j}\right|>2 t \varepsilon n, W_{i^{\prime}}$ and

$W_{j}$ do not belong to the same cluster, and thus no vertex of $B$ is in the same cluster that contains $W_{i^{\prime}}$, which implies that the vertices of $B$ have at least $\left|W_{i^{\prime}}\right|-2 t(2 \varepsilon n) \geqslant n / 2$ common neighbors in $W_{i^{\prime}}$ by (Deg). For any $i^{\prime \prime} \in[r] \backslash\{j\}$ such that $B \cap Z_{i^{\prime \prime}}^{j}=\varnothing$ (and thus $B \cap Z_{i^{\prime \prime}}=\varnothing$ ), by (Deg) we have that the vertices of $B$ have at least $n / 2$ common neighbors in $Z_{i^{\prime \prime}}$. Because $G$ is $\gamma$-close to $T$, these common neighborhoods, each of size at least $n / 2$, have densities close to one between each pair, and thus contain a copy of $K_{r-1}(t)$. Together with $B$, they form a copy of $K_{r+1}(t)$ in $G$, a contradiction.

In particular, when $b=0$ (and thus $W_{i}=\varnothing$ for all $i$ ), (Q2) implies that $Z_{i}^{j}=\varnothing$ whenever $i \neq j$. Consequently,

$$
\tilde{U}_{i}=Z_{i}^{i}=Z_{i} \backslash Z^{\prime \prime} \quad \text { for all } i \in[r] \text { when } b=0
$$

Let $L \subseteq[r]$ be the set of indices $i$ such that $\left|W_{i}\right| \geqslant(1-\varepsilon-\sqrt{\gamma}) n$. (Q2) and (Q3) imply that

- for $i \in[r] \backslash L$, we have $Z_{i}^{j}=\varnothing$ for $j \neq i$.
- for $i \in L,\left|\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}\right| \leqslant t-1$ and thus $\left|\tilde{Z}_{i}\right| \leqslant a n+t-1$.

First Estimate on $e(G)$. Let $G^{\prime}=G \cap K\left(\tilde{U}_{1}, \ldots, \tilde{U}_{r}\right)$. We have $e(G)=e\left(G^{\prime}\right)+\sum_{i=1}^{r} e_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{i}\right)+$ $e\left(Z^{\prime \prime} \cup W^{\prime \prime}, G\right)$. Since $G^{\prime}$ is $r$-partite, it is $K_{r+1}$-free. As $G^{\prime}$ is a subgraph of $G \in \mathcal{G}_{k}(n)$, we have $e\left(G^{\prime}\right) \leqslant t_{r}(k) n^{2}$ (but this is not good enough when $b>0$ ). Below we give an upper bound for $e\left(G^{\prime}\right)$, which will be used throughout the proof. Recall that $T=K\left(V_{1}, \ldots, V_{k}\right) \cap K\left(U_{1}, \ldots, U_{r}\right)$ has precisely $t_{r}(k) n^{2}$ edges.
Claim 4.3. We have $e\left(G^{\prime}\right) \leqslant t_{r}(k) n^{2}+\sum_{i \in[r]}\left(\beta_{i}-\alpha_{i}\right)$, where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \beta_{i}:=\sum_{j \in L \backslash\{i\}}\left|Z_{j}^{i}\right|\left(\left|\tilde{Z}_{j} \backslash Z_{j}\right|+\left|W_{j}^{\prime}\right|-n+\left|Z_{i} \backslash \tilde{Z}_{i}\right|\right) \text { and } \\
& \alpha_{i}:=\left|\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}\right|\left|W_{i}^{\prime}\right|+e_{T}\left(W_{i}^{\prime}\right)+e_{T}\left(\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. We first obtain $G^{(0)}:=K\left(Z_{1} \cup W_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, Z_{r} \cup W_{r}^{\prime}\right) \cap K\left(V_{1}, \ldots, V_{k}\right)$ from $T$. During this process, we lose the edges of $T$ between $W_{i}$ and $W_{j}, j \neq i$, if both ends of the edges are placed in $W_{i}^{\prime}$. Thus

$$
e\left(G^{(0)}\right)=t_{r}(k) n^{2}-\sum_{i \in[r]} e_{T}\left(W_{i}^{\prime}\right)
$$

We imagine a dynamic process of obtaining $G^{\prime}$ from $G^{(0)}$ by recursively moving vertices. To estimate $e\left(G^{\prime}\right)$, we track the changes of the edges with respect to complete $r$-partite graphs (but also respecting the $k$-partition of $G$ ). More precisely, for $l>0$, let

$$
G^{(l)}:=K\left(Z_{1}^{(l)} \cup W_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, Z_{r}^{(l)} \cup W_{r}^{\prime}\right) \cap K\left(V_{1}, \ldots, V_{k}\right)
$$

such that the $r$-partition of $G^{(l)}$ can be obtained by moving exactly one vertex from the partition of $G^{(l-1)}$. The process terminates after $m:=\sum_{i \in[r]}\left|\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}\right|$ steps and thus $G^{\prime}$ is a subgraph of $G^{(m)}$. Furthermore, throughout the process, we only move vertices from the color classes in $L$ to other color classes. Therefore, we can give a linear ordering to the members of $L$, and for $i \in L$ we move vertices from $Z_{i}$ only after we have moved the vertices in color classes $j$ prior to $i$ (denoted by $j<_{L} i$ ). Now, in the $l$-th step, suppose we move $v$ from $Z_{j}^{(l-1)}$ to $Z_{i}^{(l-1)}$, namely, $v \in Z_{j}^{i}$, then the change is

$$
e\left(G^{(l)}\right)-e\left(G^{(l-1)}\right)=\left|Z_{j}^{(l-1)} \backslash V_{p}\right|+\left|W_{j}^{\prime}\right|-\left|\tilde{Z}_{i}^{(l-1)}\right|-\left|W_{i}^{\prime}\right|
$$

where $V_{p} \ni v$ and $\tilde{Z}_{i}^{(l-1)}=Z_{i}^{(l-1)} \backslash V_{p}$.

Note that we have $\left|Z_{j}^{(l-1)} \backslash V_{p}\right| \leqslant(a-1) n+\left|\tilde{Z}_{j} \backslash Z_{j}\right|$. Moreover for any $j^{\prime}<_{L} j$, we have $Z_{j^{\prime}}^{i} \subseteq Z_{i}^{(l-1)}$. Therefore, we have $\left|\tilde{Z}_{i}^{(l-1)}\right| \geqslant a n-\left|Z_{i} \backslash \tilde{Z}_{i}\right|+\sum_{j^{\prime}<_{L} j}\left|Z_{j^{\prime}}^{i}\right|$. Putting all these together, we get

$$
e\left(G^{(l)}\right)-e\left(G^{(l-1)}\right) \leqslant\left|\tilde{Z}_{j} \backslash Z_{j}\right|+\left|W_{j}^{\prime}\right|-n+\left|Z_{i} \backslash \tilde{Z}_{i}\right|-\sum_{j^{\prime}<_{L} j}\left|Z_{j^{\prime}}^{i}\right|-\left|W_{i}^{\prime}\right|
$$

Recalling that we moved $v$ from $Z_{j}^{(l-1)}$ to $Z_{i}^{(l-1)}$ at the $l$-th step, we obtain

$$
e\left(G^{\prime}\right)-e\left(G^{(0)}\right) \leqslant \sum_{l=1}^{m}\left(\left|\tilde{Z}_{j} \backslash Z_{j}\right|+\left|W_{j}^{\prime}\right|-n+\left|Z_{i} \backslash \tilde{Z}_{i}\right|-\sum_{j^{\prime}<_{L} j}\left|Z_{j^{\prime}}^{i}\right|-\left|W_{i}^{\prime}\right|\right)
$$

where $i, j$ depends on $l$. Since $m=\sum_{i \in[r]}\left|\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}\right|$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{l=1}^{m}\left(\left|\tilde{Z}_{j} \backslash Z_{j}\right|+\left|W_{j}^{\prime}\right|-n+\left|Z_{i} \backslash \tilde{Z}_{i}\right|-\left|W_{i}^{\prime}\right|\right) \\
= & \sum_{i \in[r]} \sum_{j \in L \backslash\{i\}}\left|Z_{j}^{i}\right|\left(\left|\tilde{Z}_{j} \backslash Z_{j}\right|+\left|W_{j}^{\prime}\right|-n+\left|Z_{i} \backslash \tilde{Z}_{i}\right|-\left|W_{i}^{\prime}\right|\right) \\
= & \sum_{i \in[r]} \sum_{j \in L \backslash\{i\}}\left|Z_{j}^{i}\right|\left(\left|\tilde{Z}_{j} \backslash Z_{j}\right|+\left|W_{j}^{\prime}\right|-n+\left|Z_{i} \backslash \tilde{Z}_{i}\right|\right)-\sum_{i \in[r]}\left|\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}\right|\left|W_{i}^{\prime}\right|
\end{aligned}
$$

Moreover, it is not hard to see that

$$
\sum_{l=1}^{m} \sum_{j^{\prime}<_{L} j}\left|Z_{j^{\prime}}^{i}\right|=\sum_{i \in[r]} \sum_{\left\{j_{1}, j_{2}\right\} \in\left\{\begin{array}{c,L \\ 1 \\ 2\end{array}\right\}}\left|Z_{j_{1}}^{i}\right|\left|Z_{j_{2}}^{i}\right|=\sum_{i \in[r]} e_{T}\left(\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}\right)
$$

Now the claim follows by combining these estimates with (4.4).
What remains is to estimate the number of edges in each $\tilde{U}_{i}$. For $i \in[r]$, we have $e\left(G\left[\tilde{U}_{i}\right]\right)=$ $e\left(Z_{i}^{i}, G\left[\tilde{U}_{i}\right]\right)+e_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}^{i}\right)$. To bound $e_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}^{i}\right)=e_{G}\left(\left(\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}\right) \cup W_{i}^{\prime}\right)$, we note that $e_{G}\left(\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}, W_{i}^{\prime}\right) \leqslant$ $\left|\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}\right|\left|W_{i}^{\prime}\right|$ and $e_{G}\left(W_{i}^{\prime}\right) \leqslant e_{T}\left(W_{i}^{\prime}\right)$. However, we may not have $e_{G}\left(\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}\right) \leqslant e_{T}\left(\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}\right)$ because each $Z_{j}^{i}$ is an independent set in $T$, but may not be independent in $G$ when $a \geqslant 2$. Thus, $e_{G}\left(\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}\right) \leqslant$ $e_{T}\left(\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}\right)+\sum_{j \neq i} e_{G}\left(Z_{j}^{i}\right)$. Putting these together, for each $i \in[r]$, we have

$$
e_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}^{i}\right)=e_{G}\left(\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}, W_{i}^{\prime}\right)+e_{G}\left(W_{i}^{\prime}\right)+e_{G}\left(\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}\right) \leqslant \alpha_{i}+\sum_{j \neq i} e_{G}\left(Z_{j}^{i}\right)
$$

Let $f_{i}:=e\left(Z_{i}^{i}, G\left[\tilde{U}_{i}\right]\right)$. By Claim 4.3, (4.5) and $e(G)=e\left(G^{\prime}\right)+e\left(Z^{\prime \prime} \cup W^{\prime \prime}, G\right)+\sum_{i \in[r]} e_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{i}\right)$, we derive that

$$
\begin{aligned}
e(G) & \leqslant t_{r}(k) n^{2}+e\left(Z^{\prime \prime} \cup W^{\prime \prime}, G\right)+\sum_{i \in[r]}\left(f_{i}+\beta_{i}-\alpha_{i}+e_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}^{i}\right)\right) \\
& \leqslant t_{r}(k) n^{2}+e\left(Z^{\prime \prime} \cup W^{\prime \prime}, G\right)+\sum_{i \in[r]}\left(f_{i}+\beta_{i}+\sum_{j \neq i} e_{G}\left(Z_{j}^{i}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We now focus on the structure of each $\tilde{U}_{i}$. We first show that $G\left[\tilde{U}_{i}\right]$ is "almost" $K_{t, t}$-free.
Claim 4.4. The following holds for all $i \in[r]$.
$(K 1)$ Both $G\left[\tilde{Z}_{i}\right]$ and $G\left[Z_{i}^{i} \cup W_{i}^{\prime}\right]$ are $K_{t, t}$-free.
$(K 2)$ If $\left|W_{i}^{\prime}\right|>2 t \varepsilon n+2 \gamma n$, then $\left|W_{i}^{\prime} \backslash V_{q_{i}}\right| \leqslant t-1$.

$(K 3)$ If $\left|W_{i}^{\prime}\right|>2 t \varepsilon n+2 \gamma n$, then $G\left[\tilde{Z}_{i} \cup\left(W_{i}^{\prime} \cap V_{q_{i}}\right)\right]$ is $K_{t, t}$-free.
Proof. For (K1), suppose there is a copy of $K_{t, t}$ in $\tilde{U}_{i}$, with vertex set denoted by $B$, contained in $\tilde{Z}_{i}$ or in $Z_{i}^{t} \cup W_{i}^{\prime}$. Let $N_{B}$ be the set of common neighbors of these $2 t$ vertices of $B$. First assume that $B \subseteq \tilde{Z}_{i}$. Then for any $j \in L \backslash\{i\}$, by (Deg) we have $\left|N_{B} \cap W_{j}^{\prime}\right| \geqslant\left|W_{j}^{\prime}\right|-4 t \varepsilon n$, and thus by $(P 1)\left|N_{B} \cap W_{j} \cap W_{j}^{\prime}\right| \geqslant\left|W_{j}^{\prime}\right|-4 t \varepsilon n-2 \gamma n \geqslant n / 2$. For any $j \notin L \cup\{i\}$, because $B \cap Z_{j}=\varnothing$ by $(Q 2)$, we have $\left|N_{B} \cap Z_{j}\right| \geqslant a n-4 t \varepsilon n \geqslant n / 2$ by (Deg). Note that every set in $\left\{N_{B} \cap Z_{j}: j \notin L\right\} \cup\left\{N_{B} \cap W_{j} \cap W_{j}^{\prime}: j \in L\right\}$ has size at least $n / 2$ and every pair of them has density at least $1-4 \gamma$. Therefore we can find a copy of $K_{r-1}(t)$ in the union of these sets, which gives rise to a copy of $K_{r+1}(t)$ together with $B$, a contradiction.

Second we assume that $B \subseteq Z_{i}^{i} \cup W_{i}^{\prime}$. In this case we note that for any $j \neq i$, we have $B \cap Z_{j}=\varnothing$ and thus by (Deg), we have $\left|N_{B} \cap Z_{j}^{j}\right| \geqslant(1-\sqrt{\gamma}) a n-4 t \varepsilon n \geqslant n / 2$. Then as these sets have high pairwise densities, as in the previous case, we can find a copy of $K_{r-1}(t)$ in the union of these sets, yielding a copy of $K_{r+1}(t)$ together with $B$, a contradiction. Now $(K 1)$ is proved.

Now we turn to $(K 2)$, and suppose $\left|W_{i}^{\prime}\right|>2 t \varepsilon n+2 \gamma n$ and thus $\left|W_{i} \cap W_{i}^{\prime}\right|>2 t \varepsilon n$ by $(P 1)$. First, if $W_{i}^{\prime}$ contains at least $t$ vertices which are not from $V_{q_{i}}$ (the cluster containing $W_{i}$ ), then by (Deg), each of these vertices have at most $2 \varepsilon n$ non-neighbors in $W_{i} \cap W_{i}^{\prime}$, and thus we can find a copy of $K_{t, t}$ in $W_{i}^{\prime}$, contradicting (K1). So we have $\left|W_{i}^{\prime} \backslash V_{q_{i}}\right| \leqslant t-1$.

For (K3), suppose there is a copy of $K_{t, t}$ as stated in the claim, whose vertex set is denoted by $B$. As in the previous paragraph, we have $\left|W_{i}\right|>2 t \varepsilon n$ by $(P 1)$. Now observe crucially that if $B \cap Z_{j}^{i} \neq \varnothing$, then by $(Q 2)\left|W_{i}\right|+\left|W_{j}\right|>n$, and thus, $W_{i}$ and $W_{j}$ are not from the same cluster. So by (Deg), for any $j \in[r-1] \backslash\{i\}$, if $B \cap Z_{j}^{i}=\varnothing$, then the vertices of $B$ have large common neighborhoods in $Z_{j}^{j}$; if $B \cap Z_{j}^{i} \neq \varnothing$, then the vertices of $B$ have large common neighborhoods in $W_{j} \cap W_{j}^{\prime}$ (note that $\left|W_{j}\right| \geqslant(1-\varepsilon-\sqrt{\gamma}) n$ by $(Q 2)$ ). Since each of these common neighborhoods have size at least $n / 2$ and each pair of them has high density, we can find a copy of $K_{r-1}(t)$ in the union of these sets, yielding a copy of $K_{r+1}(t)$ together with $B$, a contradiction.

We now derive a lower bound for $\sum f_{i}$ from Claims 4.3 and 4.4. For $i \in[r]$, we have $\beta_{i} \leqslant$ $\sum_{j \in L \backslash\{i\}}\left|Z_{j}^{i}\right|\left(\left|\tilde{Z}_{j} \backslash Z_{j}\right|+\left|W_{j}^{\prime} \backslash V_{q_{j}}\right|+\left|Z_{i} \backslash \tilde{Z}_{i}\right|\right)$ as $\left|W_{j}^{\prime}\right|-n \leqslant\left|W_{j}^{\prime} \backslash V_{q_{j}}\right|$. Fix $j \in L \backslash\{i\}$. Note that $\left|W_{j}\right| \geqslant(1-2 \varepsilon) n$. We have $\left|\tilde{Z}_{j} \backslash Z_{j}\right| \leqslant t-1$ by $(Q 3)$, and $\left|W_{j}^{\prime} \backslash V_{q_{j}}\right| \leqslant t-1$ by $(K 2)$. If $\left|W_{i}\right|>n / 2$, then $\left|Z_{j}^{i}\right| \leqslant t-1$ by $(Q 3)$. Furthermore, since $\left|Z_{i} \backslash \tilde{Z}_{i}\right| \leqslant(r-1) \sqrt{\gamma} n+C_{0}$ by $(P 3)$, it follows that

$$
\left|Z_{j}^{i}\right|\left(\left|\tilde{Z}_{j} \backslash Z_{j}\right|+\left|W_{j}^{\prime} \backslash V_{q_{j}}\right|+\left|Z_{i} \backslash \tilde{Z}_{i}\right|\right) \leqslant(t-1)(t-1+t-1+(r-1) \sqrt{\gamma} n+C_{0}) \leqslant(t-1) r \sqrt{\gamma} n
$$

Otherwise $\left|W_{i}\right| \leqslant n / 2$, and by $(Q 2)$, we have $Z_{i}^{i^{\prime}}=\varnothing$ for any $i^{\prime} \neq i$. This implies $\left|Z_{i} \backslash \tilde{Z}_{i}\right|=\left|Z_{i}^{\prime \prime}\right| \leqslant$ $C_{0}$. Using $\left|Z_{j}^{i}\right| \leqslant \sqrt{\gamma} n,(Q 3)$, and $(K 2)$, we derive that

$$
\left|Z_{j}^{i}\right|\left(\left|\tilde{Z}_{j} \backslash Z_{j}\right|+\left|W_{j}^{\prime} \backslash V_{q_{j}}\right|+\left|Z_{i} \backslash \tilde{Z}_{i}\right|\right) \leqslant \sqrt{\gamma} n\left(2(t-1)+C_{0}\right) \leqslant 2 C_{0} \sqrt{\gamma} n
$$

Summarizing these two cases for all $j \in L \backslash\{i\}$, we obtain that $\beta_{i} \leqslant(r-1) 2 C_{0} \sqrt{\gamma} n$, and consequently,

$$
\sum_{i \in[r]} \beta_{i} \leqslant 2(r-1) r C_{0} \sqrt{\gamma} n
$$

On the other hand, for all $i \neq j$, the graph $G\left[Z_{j}^{t}\right]$ is $K_{t, t}$-free by $(K 1)$ and thus, by $(P 3)$, $\sum_{i, j: i \neq j} e_{G}\left(Z_{j}^{i}\right) \leqslant r(r-1) C(\sqrt{\gamma} n)^{2-1 / t}$. Applying this with (4.7), (4.8), and the fact that $e\left(Z^{\prime \prime} \cup\right.$

$W^{\prime \prime}, G) \leqslant(r+1) C_{0} k n$, we obtain that

$$
\begin{aligned}
e(G) & \leqslant t_{r}(k) n^{2}+(r+1) C_{0} k n+\sum_{i \in[r]} f_{i}+2(r-1) r C_{0} \sqrt{\gamma} n+\sum_{i, j: i \neq j} e_{G}\left(Z_{j}^{i}\right) \\
& \leqslant t_{r}(k) n^{2}+\sum_{i \in[r]} f_{i}+r^{2} C \sqrt{\gamma} n^{2-1 / t}
\end{aligned}
$$

as $\gamma \ll 1$. Using the assumption $e(G) \geqslant g(n, r, k, t) \geqslant t_{r}(k) n^{2}+z_{t}(n)$, we infer that

$$
\sum_{i \in[r]} f_{i} \geqslant z_{t}(n)-r^{2} C \sqrt{\gamma} n^{2-1 / t} \geqslant \frac{c}{2} n^{2-1 / t}
$$

by using $(Z), z_{t}(n) \geqslant z_{t}^{(2)}(n) \geqslant c n^{2-1 / t}$, and $\gamma \ll 1$.
We next study the existence of $K_{1, t}$ in each color class. To do so, we consider a copy of $K_{3}(t)$ in $G\left[\tilde{U}_{i} \cup \tilde{U}_{j}\right]$ for some $i \neq j$.

Claim 4.5. For any $i \neq j$, if $G\left[\tilde{U}_{i} \cup \tilde{U}_{j}\right]$ contains a copy $K$ of $K_{3}(t)$, then there exists $l \notin\{i, j\}$ such that $V(K)$ intersects $V_{\# i}$ and every cluster in $Z_{l}$.

Proof. We may assume that $r>2$ as otherwise the claim is trivial. Suppose to the contrary that there is a copy $K$ of $K_{3}(t)$ in, say, $\tilde{U}_{1}$ and $\tilde{U}_{2}$, such that for every $l \in[3, r]$, there is a cluster in $U_{l}$ which does not intersect $B:=V(K)$. Let $V_{i_{l}}$ be a cluster in $Z_{l}$ such that $B \cap V_{i_{l}}=\varnothing$, and if there is no such cluster in $Z_{l}$, then we choose $V_{i_{l}}=V_{\# i}$. Note that in the former case, we have $\left|\tilde{U}_{l} \cap V_{i_{l}}\right|=\left|Z_{l}^{l} \cap V_{i_{l}}\right| \geqslant(1-\sqrt{\gamma} a) n$. In the latter case, we have $Z_{l}^{1} \neq \varnothing$ or $Z_{l}^{2} \neq \varnothing$, which implies that $\left|W_{l}\right| \geqslant(1-2 \varepsilon) n$ by $(Q 2)$, and thus $\left|\tilde{U}_{l} \cap V_{i_{l}}\right|=\left|W_{l}^{\prime} \cap V_{i_{l}}\right| \geqslant(1-3 \varepsilon) n$. Now, by (Deg), every vertex in $B$ has at most $2 \varepsilon n$ non-neighbors in $\tilde{U}_{l} \cap V_{i_{l}}$ for each $l \in[3, r]$. Since for every $l$ we have $\left|\tilde{U}_{l} \cap V_{i_{l}}\right| \geqslant 0.9 n$, one can find large common neighborhoods (e.g. of size $n / 2$ ) of all vertices of $B$ in each $\tilde{U}_{l} \cap V_{i_{l}}$, and then find a copy of $K_{r-2}(t)$ in these sets. Altogether we obtain a copy of $K_{r+1}(t)$, a contradiction.

Therefore, for such a copy $K$ of $K_{3}(t)$, there exists $l \notin\{i, j\}$ such that $K$ must intersect all clusters of $U_{l}$. Since $V(K) \cap Z_{l} \neq \varnothing$, we have $Z_{l}^{i} \neq \varnothing$ or $Z_{l}^{j} \neq \varnothing$. Then by $(Q 2),\left|W_{l}\right| \geqslant(1-2 \varepsilon) n$ and in particular, $V_{\# i} \neq \varnothing$. Therefore $V(K) \cap V_{\# i} \neq \varnothing$.

Claim 4.6. For all but exactly one $j \in[r]$, we have $d\left(v, Z_{j}^{j}\right) \leqslant t-1$ for all $v \in \tilde{U}_{j}$.
Proof. First assume that there exists $j \in[r]$ such that $G\left[\tilde{U}_{j}\right]$ contains a copy of $K_{1, t}$, with vertex set denoted by $\left\{v, u_{1}, \ldots, u_{t}\right\}, v \in \tilde{U}_{j}$ and $u_{1}, \ldots, u_{t} \in Z_{j}^{j}$. Fix $i \in[r] \backslash\{j\}$ and let $N^{\prime}$ be the set of common neighbors of $u_{1}, \ldots, u_{t}$ in $\tilde{U}_{i} \cap U_{i}$. Suppose $v \in V_{p}$ and let $N$ be the set of common neighbors of these $t+1$ vertices in $\tilde{U}_{i} \cap U_{i}$. In particular, $N \subseteq N^{\prime}$ and $N$ is almost equal to the union of $a$ or $a+1$ clusters in $\tilde{U}_{i}$. Suppose there is a copy of $K_{t-1, t}$ with parts $S_{1}$ of size $t-1$ and $S_{2}$ of size $t$ such that $S_{1} \subseteq N^{\prime}$ and $S_{2} \subseteq N$. Then by Claim 4.5, there exists $l \in[r] \backslash\{i, j\}$ such that $B \cap Z_{l} \neq \varnothing$ and $B \cap V_{\# i} \neq \varnothing$, where $B$ denotes the vertex set of the copy of $K_{3}(t)$. This is impossible since $v$ is the only possible vertex in $B \cap\left(Z_{l} \cup V_{\# i}\right)$ and can not satisfy both. Therefore, letting $N^{*}=N \cup\left(N^{\prime} \cap V_{p}\right)$, we infer that $e_{G}\left(N^{*}\right)=e_{G}(N)+e_{G}\left(N, N^{\prime} \backslash N\right)=O\left(n^{2-1 /(t-1)}\right)$.

By $(P 1),(P 3)$ and (Deg), we have $\left|\tilde{U}_{i} \backslash N^{*}\right| \leqslant 3(t+1) \varepsilon n$. Let $E^{i}$ be the set of the edges incident to $\tilde{U}_{i} \backslash N^{*}$ and counted in $f_{i}$. We split it to $E^{i} \cap E_{G}\left(Z_{i}^{i}\right)$ and $E^{i} \cap E_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}^{i}, Z_{i}^{i}\right)$. Note that by ( $K 1$ ), each of the terms can be split further into at most $k K_{t, t}$-free bipartite graphs, each with one part

of size at most $3(t+1) \varepsilon n$ and the other part of size at most $(1+(r-2) \sqrt{\gamma}) a n$. Therefore, we obtain that

$$
f_{i}=O\left(\varepsilon n^{2-1 / t}\right)+O\left(n^{2-1 /(t-1)}\right)=O\left(\varepsilon n^{2-1 / t}\right)
$$

Now assume there exist distinct $j_{1}, j_{2} \in[r]$ such that each $G\left[\tilde{U}_{j_{i}}\right]$ contains a copy of $K_{1, t}$ whose part of size $t$ is in $Z_{j_{i}}^{j_{i}}$. The arguments above imply that (4.10) holds for all $i \in[r]$, and consequently, $\sum_{i \in[r]} f_{i}=O\left(\varepsilon n^{2-1 / t}\right)$, contradicting (4.9).

On the other hand, if $d\left(v, Z_{j}^{j}\right) \leqslant t-1$ for all $j \in[r]$ and all $v \in \tilde{U}_{j}$, then $\sum_{j \in[r]} f_{j} \leqslant(t-1) k n$, again contradicting (4.9).

By Claim 4.6, without loss of generality, we assume that,

$$
\text { for } i \geqslant 2, \quad d\left(v, Z_{i}^{i}\right) \leqslant t-1 \text { for all } v \in \tilde{U}_{i}, \quad \text { and thus, } \quad f_{i} \leqslant \begin{cases}(t-1)\left|\tilde{U}_{i}\right| & \text { if } a \geqslant 2 \\ (t-1)\left|\tilde{U}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}^{i}\right| & \text { if } a=1\end{cases}
$$

If $b=0$, then $\tilde{U}_{i}=Z_{i}^{i}=Z_{i} \backslash Z^{\prime \prime}$ for all $i$ by (4.3). In this case $\tilde{U}_{1}$ is $K_{t, t}$-free by ( $K 1$ ) and $\tilde{U}_{i}$ is $K_{1, t}$-free for all $i \geqslant 2$ by (4.11). Since $G$ is $\gamma$-close to $K_{r}(a n), G\left[U_{i} \backslash Z^{\prime \prime}, U_{j} \backslash Z^{\prime \prime}\right]$ is almost complete for all $i \neq j$. This completes the proof of Theorem 4 with $Z:=Z^{\prime \prime}$.

By (4.9) and (4.11), we get

$$
f_{1} \geqslant z_{t}(n)-\varepsilon n^{2-1 / t}
$$

In particular, we claim that

$$
\left|W_{1}\right|>3 t \varepsilon n \quad \text { if } b>0
$$

(which we will refine a moment later). Indeed, the edges counted in $f_{1}$ can be covered by $G\left[Z_{1}^{1}\right]$, $G\left[Z_{1}^{1}, W_{1} \cap W_{1}^{\prime}\right]$, and at most $k K_{t, t}$-free bipartite graphs, each with a part of size at most $\sqrt{\gamma} n$ and a part of size at most $a n$. If $\left|W_{1}\right| \leqslant 3 t \varepsilon n$, then $e_{G}\left(Z_{1}^{1}, W_{1} \cap W_{1}^{\prime}\right)=O\left(\varepsilon n^{2-1 / t}\right)$. Together with $e_{G}\left(Z_{1}^{1}\right) \leqslant z_{t}^{(a)}(n)$, we have

$$
f_{1} \leqslant z_{t}^{(a)}(n)+O\left(\varepsilon n^{2-1 / t}\right)<z_{t}^{(a+1)}(n)-\varepsilon n^{2-1 / t}
$$

by $(E 1)$, contradicting (4.12).
Now we can give a much cleaner structure, shown in a series of claims below. A key step is to show that $Z^{\prime \prime} \cup W^{\prime \prime}=\varnothing$. From now on we only consider $k \leqslant 2 r$.
Claim 4.7. Suppose $v_{0} \in V(G)$ and $i \in[r]$ satisfy that $v_{0}$ has at least $\varepsilon n$ neighbors in $Z_{j}$ for every $j \neq i$. Then $v_{0}$ has less than $\varepsilon n$ neighbors in $U_{i}$. In particular, we have $Z^{\prime \prime}=\varnothing$ and $W^{\prime \prime}=\varnothing$.
Proof. The second part of the claim follows immediately from the definitions of $Z^{\prime \prime}$ and $W^{\prime \prime}$.
Suppose to the contrary, that there exist $v_{0} \in V(G)$ and $i \in[r]$ such that $v_{0}$ has at least $\varepsilon n$ neighbors in $Z_{j}$ for every $j \neq i$ and at least $\varepsilon n$ neighbors in $U_{i}$. Since $\left|Z_{j}^{j}\right| \geqslant(1-\sqrt{\gamma}) a n$ for all $j \in[r]$, there exist sets $N_{1}, \ldots, N_{r-1}$ each of size $\varepsilon n-\sqrt{\gamma} n$ such that $N_{j} \subseteq Z_{j}^{j} \cap N\left(v_{0}\right)$ for $j \neq i$ and $N_{i} \subseteq\left(Z_{i}^{i} \cup W_{i}\right) \cap N\left(v_{0}\right)$. Recall that $W_{1}^{\prime}=W_{1}^{\prime} \cap V_{q_{1}}$. By averaging, there exists $N_{1}^{\prime} \subseteq N_{1}$ with $\left|N_{1}^{\prime}\right| \geqslant(\varepsilon n-\sqrt{\gamma} n-2 r \gamma n) / 2 \geqslant \varepsilon n / 3$ such that all vertices of $N_{1}^{\prime}$ are in $Z_{1}^{1} \cup W_{1}^{\prime}$ and from the same cluster, that is,

$$
N_{1}^{\prime} \subseteq Q, \text { where } Q \in\left\{Z_{1}^{1}, W_{1}^{\prime}\right\}
$$

Note that $N_{1}^{\prime} \subseteq W_{1}^{\prime}$ is possible only if $i=1$ and $a=1$. If $i \neq 1$, then let $N_{i}^{\prime}:=N_{i} \backslash\left(\left(W_{i} \backslash W_{i}^{\prime}\right) \cup V_{q_{1}}\right)$ and for every $j \in[r] \backslash\{1, i\}$, let $N_{j}^{\prime}:=N_{j}$. By $(P 1),\left|W_{i} \backslash W_{i}^{\prime}\right| \leqslant 2 r \gamma n$, and by (4.16), $\left|W_{i} \cap V_{q_{1}}\right| \leqslant \gamma n$. Thus, we have $\left|N_{j}^{\prime}\right| \geqslant \varepsilon n / 3$ for all $j \in[r]$. Because the sets $N_{j}^{\prime}$ are small, we can not apply the degree conditions (Deg) to them and instead, we use (D0).

Recall that $B_{1}$ is given by (D0). Next we show that $G\left[\tilde{U}_{1} \backslash B_{1}\right]$ does not contain a copy of $K_{t-1, t}$ such that the part of size $t$ is in $N_{1}^{\prime}$. Suppose instead, there is such a copy of $K_{t-1, t}$, with parts denoted by $A$ and $B$, such that $|A|=t, A \subseteq N_{1}^{\prime} \backslash B_{1}$ and $B \subseteq \tilde{U}_{1} \backslash B_{1}$. Recall that $N_{i}^{\prime} \cap V_{q_{1}}=\varnothing$ and for each $j \in[r] \backslash\{1, i\}, N_{j}^{\prime} \subseteq Z_{j}^{j}$. Observe that for every $v \in \tilde{U}_{1} \backslash B_{1}$, we have $d\left(v, N_{j}^{\prime}\right) \geqslant\left|N_{j}^{\prime}\right|-\sqrt{\gamma} n$. Indeed, if $j \neq i$, then $N_{j}^{\prime} \subseteq Z_{j}^{j}$ and we have $d\left(v, N_{j}^{\prime}\right) \geqslant\left|N_{j}^{\prime}\right|-\sqrt{\gamma} n$ by (D0); otherwise note that $N_{i}^{\prime} \subseteq Z_{i}^{i} \cup\left(W_{i}^{\prime} \cap W_{i}\right)$, and by (D0) and $N_{i}^{\prime} \cap V_{q_{1}}=\varnothing$ we have $d\left(v, N_{i}^{\prime}\right) \geqslant\left|N_{i}^{\prime}\right|-\sqrt{\gamma} n$. Therefore, we obtain that the vertices in $A \cup B$ have at least $\left|N_{j}^{\prime}\right|-(2 t-1) \sqrt{\gamma} n \geqslant\left(1-\gamma^{1 / 3}\right)\left|N_{j}^{\prime}\right|$ common neighbors in each $N_{j}^{\prime}, j \in[2, r]$. Because each pair $N_{j}^{\prime}, N_{j^{\prime}}^{\prime}$ has a high density, we can find a copy of $K_{r-1}(t)$ in the union of these common neighborhoods, which together with $A \cup B \cup\left\{v_{0}\right\}$ form a copy of $K_{r+1}(t)$, a contradiction.

Now given that $G\left[\tilde{U}_{1} \backslash B_{1}\right]$ does not contain a copy of $K_{t-1, t}$ such that the part of size $t$ is in $N_{1}^{\prime} \backslash B_{1}$, we give a refined estimate on $f_{1}$. Indeed, since $G\left[N_{1}^{\prime} \backslash B_{1}, Z_{1}^{1} \backslash B_{1}\right]$ does not contain a copy of $K_{t-1, t}$ such that the part of size $t$ is in $N_{1}^{\prime} \backslash B_{1}$, we get $e_{G}\left(N_{1}^{\prime} \backslash B_{1}, Z_{1}^{1} \backslash B_{1}\right)=O\left(n^{2-1 /(t-1)}\right)$. Similarly $e_{G}\left(N_{1}^{\prime} \backslash B_{1}, W_{1}^{\prime} \backslash B_{1}\right)=O\left(n^{2-1 /(t-1)}\right)$. Suppose $N_{1}^{\prime} \subseteq V_{q}$ for some $q \in\left\{1, q_{1}\right\}$, then we have

$$
E\left(G\left[\tilde{U}_{1}\right]\right)=E\left(G\left[\tilde{U}_{1} \backslash\left(N_{1}^{\prime} \backslash B_{1}\right)\right]\right) \cup E\left(G\left[N_{1}^{\prime} \backslash B_{1}, \tilde{U}_{1} \backslash\left(B_{1} \cup V_{q}\right)\right]\right) \cup E\left(G\left[N_{1}^{\prime} \backslash B_{1}, B_{1} \cap \tilde{U}_{1}\right)\right)
$$

Recall that $\left|N_{1}^{\prime}\right| \geqslant \varepsilon n / 3$ and $\left|B_{1}\right| \leqslant 2 \sqrt{\gamma} n$. Therefore, (regardless of $a=1$ or $(a, b)=(2,0)$ ) we can bound $f_{1} \leqslant\left|E\left(G\left[\tilde{U}_{1}\right]\right)\right|$ by

$$
f_{1} \leqslant z_{t}\left(\left(1-\frac{\varepsilon}{3}\right) n, n\right)+O\left(n^{2-1 /(t-1)}\right)+O\left(\sqrt{\gamma} n^{2-1 / t}\right)<z_{t}(n)-3 r C_{0} k n
$$

where we used (E2) and $\gamma \ll \varepsilon$. This contradicts (4.12).
When $a=2$ and $b=0$ (i.e., $k=2 r$ ), since $Z_{i}^{\prime \prime}=\varnothing$ and $W_{i}=\varnothing$ for all $i \in[r]$, by (4.3), we get $\tilde{U}_{i}=Z_{i}$ for all $i \in[r]$. Therefore $e(G)=e\left(G^{\prime}\right)+\sum_{i=1}^{r} e_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{i}\right)+e\left(Z^{\prime \prime} \cup W^{\prime \prime}, G\right) \leqslant t_{r}(k) n^{2}+z_{t}(n)+$ $(r-1)(t-1) n$ by $(K 1)$ and (4.11), proving Theorem 3 for $k=2 r$.

For the remaining of the proof, we only need to consider $a=1$ (and thus $b>0$ ). Moreover, now for $i, j \in[r]$ each $Z_{i}^{j} \subseteq Z_{i}$ is an independent set and thus $e_{G}\left(Z_{i}^{j}\right)=0$. So we can first update our bounds on $e(G)$ and $f_{1}$. Recall the bounds $(4.7),(4.8)$ and (4.11) and we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
e(G) & \leqslant t_{r}(k) n^{2}+\sum_{i \in[r]}\left(f_{i}+\beta_{i}\right) \\
& \leqslant t_{r}(k) n^{2}+f_{1}+(r-1)(t-1)(1+\sqrt{\gamma}) n+2(r-1) r C_{0} \sqrt{\gamma} n
\end{aligned}
$$

yielding

$$
f_{1} \geqslant z_{t}(n, n)-C_{0} n
$$

Claim 4.8. Suppose $b>0$. Then $\tilde{U}_{1}=Z_{1}^{1} \cup W_{1}^{\prime}$ and $W_{1}^{\prime} \subseteq V_{q_{1}}$.
Proof. Suppose to the contrary, there is a vertex $v$ in $\tilde{U}_{1} \backslash\left(Z_{1}^{1} \cup W_{1}^{\prime}\right)$ or $W_{1}^{\prime} \backslash V_{q_{1}}$, namely, $v \in Z_{i}^{1}$ for some $2 \leqslant i \leqslant r$ or $v \in W_{1}^{\prime} \backslash V_{q_{1}}$. Suppose $v \in V_{l}$. Then $l \neq q_{1}$. Moreover, if $i$ is defined, then $W_{1}^{\prime} \cap V_{q_{1}} \subseteq V \backslash\left(\tilde{Z}_{i} \cup V_{l}\right)$; otherwise, $W_{1}^{\prime} \cap V_{q_{1}} \subseteq V \backslash V_{l}$. By (Deg), we have $\bar{d}\left(v, W_{1}^{\prime} \cap V_{q_{1}}\right) \leqslant 2 \varepsilon n$. Let $N:=W_{1}^{\prime} \cap V_{q_{1}} \cap N(v)$. We have $\left|\left(W_{1}^{\prime} \cap V_{q_{1}}\right) \backslash N\right| \leqslant 2 \varepsilon N$. Since $\left|W_{1}^{\prime} \backslash V_{q_{1}}\right| \leqslant\left|W_{1}^{\prime}\right| W_{1} \mid \leqslant 2 \gamma n$, it follows that $\left|W_{1}^{\prime} \backslash N\right| \leqslant 2 \varepsilon n+2 \gamma n \leqslant 3 \varepsilon n$.

Recall (4.13), $\left|W_{1}\right|>3 t \varepsilon n$. By (K3) (if $v \in \tilde{Z}_{1} \backslash Z_{1}$ ) or (K1) (if $v \in W_{1}^{\prime} \backslash V_{q_{1}}$ ), we know that $G\left[Z_{1}^{1}, N\right]$ contains no $K_{t-1, t}$ with the part of size $t$ in $N$. This implies that $e_{G}\left(Z_{1}^{1}, N\right)=O\left(n^{2-1 /(t-1)}\right)$. Furthermore, by $(P 3)$ and $(K 1), G\left[\tilde{Z}_{1} \backslash Z_{1}^{1}, Z_{1}^{1}\right]$ is a $K_{t, t}$-free bipartite graph with one part of size at

most $(r-1) \sqrt{\gamma} n$ and the other part of size at most $n$. Thus, $e_{G}\left(\tilde{Z}_{1} \backslash Z_{1}^{1}, Z_{1}^{1}\right) \leqslant C(r-1) \sqrt{\gamma} n^{2-1 / t}$. By the similar arguments, we have $e_{G}\left(W_{1}^{\prime} \backslash N, Z_{1}^{1}\right) \leqslant C(3 \varepsilon n) n^{1-1 / t}$.

Putting these bounds together (and note that $Z_{1}^{1}$ is an independent set, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
f_{1} & =e_{G}\left(Z_{1}^{1}, N\right)+e_{G}\left(\tilde{Z}_{1} \backslash Z_{1}^{1}, Z_{1}^{1}\right)+e_{G}\left(W_{1}^{\prime} \backslash N, Z_{1}^{1}\right) \\
& =O\left(n^{2-1 /(t-1)}\right)+O\left(\sqrt{\gamma} n^{2-1 / t}\right)+O\left(\varepsilon n^{2-1 / t}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

By (E1), this contradicts (4.14).
Claim 4.8 shows that $\tilde{U}_{1}$ has no atypical vertices and is thus $K_{t, t}$-free by ( $K 1$ ). Furthermore, since $\tilde{U}_{1}=Z_{1}^{1} \cup W_{1}^{\prime}$ and $W_{1}^{\prime} \subseteq V_{q_{1}}$, it follows that

$$
\alpha_{1}=\beta_{1}=0, \quad \text { and } \quad e_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{1}\right)=f_{1} \leqslant z_{t}\left(\left|Z_{1}^{1}\right|,\left|W_{1}^{\prime}\right|\right)
$$

Therefore, if $\left|W_{1}^{\prime}\right| \leqslant(1-\gamma) n$, then we have $f_{1} \leqslant z_{t}\left(n,\left|W_{1}^{\prime}\right|\right) \leqslant z_{t}(n, n)-\delta n^{2-1 / t}$ for some $\delta>0$ by (E2). This contradicts (4.14). So we obtain

$$
\text { if } a=1 \text {, then }\left|W_{1}^{\prime}\right| \geqslant(1-\gamma) n \quad(\text { and thus } \quad 1 \in L)
$$

Next we study $G\left[\tilde{U}_{i}\right]$ for $i \geqslant 2$. A key observation is that copies of $K_{1, t}$ in $G\left[\tilde{U}_{i}\right]$ together with copies of $K_{t-1, t}$ in $\tilde{U}_{1}$ may form copies of $K_{3}(t)$, which are restricted by Claim 4.5.
Claim 4.9. Suppose $i \in[2, r]$.
(1) If there is a copy of $K_{1, t}$ in $\tilde{U}_{i} \backslash\left(Z_{1} \cup V_{q_{1}}\right)$, then there exists $l \in[r] \backslash\{i\}$ such that the vertex set of $K_{1, t}$ intersects both $V_{q_{l}}$ and $Z_{l}$.
(2) Both $\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash Z_{1}$ and $Z_{i}^{i} \cup\left(W_{i}^{\prime} \backslash V_{q_{1}}\right)$ are $K_{1, t}$-free.

Proof. For Part (1), let $B$ be the vertex set of a copy of $K_{1, t}$ in $\tilde{U}_{i} \backslash\left(Z_{1} \cup V_{q_{1}}\right)$. Since $B \cap\left(Z_{1} \cup V_{q_{1}}\right)=\varnothing$ and $\tilde{U}_{1} \subseteq Z_{1} \cup V_{q_{1}}$, by (Deg), all vertices of $B$ have at most $2 \varepsilon n$ non-neighbors in $\tilde{U}_{1}$. Letting $N:=\tilde{U}_{1} \cap \bigcap_{w \in B} N(w)$, we have $|N| \geqslant|\tilde{U}_{1}|-(t+1) 2 \varepsilon n$.

First assume that $N$ is $K_{t-1, t}$-free and thus $e_{G}(N)=O\left(n^{2-1 /(t-1)}\right)$. Note that, since $\left|\tilde{U}_{1} \backslash N\right| \leqslant$ $(t+1) 2 \varepsilon n$, the edges in $\tilde{U}_{1}$ incident to $\tilde{U}_{1} \backslash N$ can be split into two bipartite $K_{t, t}$-free graphs each with one part of size at most $(t+1) 2 \varepsilon n$ and the other part of size at most $n$. Thus, the number of such edges is $O\left(\varepsilon n^{2-1 / t}\right)$. This gives $f_{1}=O\left(n^{2-1 /(t-1)}\right)+O\left(\varepsilon n^{2-1 / t}\right)$, contradicting (4.12).

We thus assume $N$ contains a copy of $K_{t-1, t}$. Together with $B$, they form a copy of $K_{3}(t)$ in $G\left[\tilde{U}_{1} \cup \tilde{U}_{i}\right]$ and we denote its vertex set by $B^{\prime}$. By Claim 4.5, there exists $l \notin\{1, i\}$ such that $B^{\prime}$ intersects $V_{q_{l}}$ and $Z_{l}$.
