By Claim 4.8, $\tilde{U}_{1} \cap U_{l}=\varnothing$, so $B^{\prime} \cap Z_{l}=B \cap Z_{l}$ and $B$ indeed intersects $Z_{l}$. Since $\tilde{U}_{i} \cap Z_{l} \supseteq B \cap Z_{l} \neq \varnothing$, we infer that $\left|W_{l}\right| \geqslant(1-2 \varepsilon) n$ from (Q3), which implies that $q_{l} \neq q_{1}$ because of (4.13). It follows that $W_{1} \cap V_{q_{l}}=\varnothing$ and thus $B \cap V_{q_{l}}=B^{\prime} \cap V_{q_{l}} \neq \varnothing$, as desired.

For Part (2), let $A_{i}:=Z_{i}^{i} \cup\left(W_{i}^{\prime} \backslash V_{q_{1}}\right)$ and $B$ be the vertex set of a copy of $K_{1, t}$ in $\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash Z_{1}$ or in $A_{i}$. Then, by the first part of the claim, there exists $l \in[r] \backslash\{i\}$ such that $B$ intersects $V_{q_{l}}$ and $Z_{l}$. This is impossible if $B \subseteq A_{i}$ because $A_{i} \cap Z_{l}=\varnothing$ for any $l \notin\{1, i\}$, and also impossible if $B \subseteq \tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash Z_{1}$ because in which case $B \cap W=\varnothing$ and thus $B \cap V_{q_{l}}=\varnothing$ for any $l \notin\{1, i\}$.

The following claim shows a clean structure for the $\tilde{U}_{i}$ such that $W_{i}^{\prime}$ is not too small.
Claim 4.10. For $i \in[2, r]$ such that $\left|W_{i}\right| \geqslant 2 \varepsilon n$, we have $\tilde{U}_{i} \subseteq U_{i} \cup V_{q_{i}}$.
Proof. Suppose instead, for some $i_{0} \in[2, r]$ with $\left|W_{i_{0}}\right| \geqslant 2 \varepsilon n$, there exists $v \in \tilde{U}_{i_{0}} \backslash\left(U_{i_{0}} \cup V_{q_{i_{0}}}\right)$. By $(P 4)$ and the fact that $v \in \tilde{U}_{i_{0}} \backslash U_{i_{0}}$, we infer that $d\left(v, Z_{j}\right) \geqslant \varepsilon n$ for all $j \neq i_{0}$. Then, by Claim 4.7, we have $d\left(v, U_{i_{0}}\right)<\varepsilon n$. Consequently, $d\left(v, W_{i_{0}}^{\prime} \cap W_{i_{0}}\right)<\varepsilon n$, namely, $v$ has at least

$2 \varepsilon n-2 \gamma n-\varepsilon n \geqslant(1 / 2) \varepsilon n$ non-neighbors in $W_{i_{0}}^{\prime} \cap W_{i_{0}}$ (in $G$ ). Note that $v$ is adjacent to all the vertices of $W_{i_{0}}^{\prime} \cap W_{i_{0}}$ in $T$. Since $G\left[W_{i_{0}}^{\prime}\right] \subseteq T\left[W_{i_{0}}^{\prime}\right]$, we infer that

$$
e_{G}\left(W_{i_{0}}^{\prime}\right)+e_{G}\left(\tilde{Z}_{i_{0}} \backslash Z_{i_{0}}, W_{i_{0}}^{\prime}\right) \leqslant e_{T}\left(W_{i_{0}}^{\prime}\right)+\left|\tilde{Z}_{i_{0}} \backslash Z_{i_{0}}\right|\left|W_{i_{0}}^{\prime}\right|-(1 / 2) \varepsilon n
$$

Since $e_{G}\left(\tilde{Z}_{i_{0}} \backslash Z_{i_{0}}\right) \leqslant e_{T}\left(\tilde{Z}_{i_{0}} \backslash Z_{i_{0}}\right)$ and $\alpha_{i_{0}}=\left|\tilde{Z}_{i_{0}} \backslash Z_{i_{0}}\right|\left|W_{i}^{\prime}\right|+e_{T}\left(W_{i_{0}}^{\prime}\right)+e_{T}\left(\tilde{Z}_{i_{0}} \backslash Z_{i_{0}}\right)$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
e_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{i_{0}} \backslash Z_{i_{0}}\right) & =e_{G}\left(\tilde{Z}_{i_{0}} \backslash Z_{i_{0}}\right)+e_{G}\left(W_{i_{0}}^{\prime}\right)+e_{G}\left(\tilde{Z}_{i_{0}} \backslash Z_{i_{0}}, W_{i_{0}}^{\prime}\right) \\
& \leqslant e_{T}\left(\tilde{Z}_{i_{0}} \backslash Z_{i_{0}}\right)+e_{T}\left(W_{i_{0}}^{\prime}\right)+\left|\tilde{Z}_{i_{0}} \backslash Z_{i_{0}}\right|\left|W_{i_{0}}^{\prime}\right|-(1 / 2) \varepsilon n \\
& \leqslant \alpha_{i_{0}}-(1 / 2) \varepsilon n
\end{aligned}
$$

Combining (4.5) and (4.17) gives

$$
\sum_{i \in[r]} e_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}\right) \leqslant \sum_{i \in[r]} \alpha_{i}-(1 / 2) \varepsilon n
$$

Recall that $f_{i} \leqslant(t-1)\left|\tilde{U}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}\right|(i \geqslant 2)$ by $(4.11),\left|W_{1}^{\prime}\right| \geqslant(1-\gamma) n$ by (4.16), and $\left|Z_{i}^{i}\right| \geqslant(1-\sqrt{\gamma}) n$ by $(P 3)$. Therefore, as $\sum_{i=1}^{r}\left|\tilde{U}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}\right| \leqslant(b-1) n+r \sqrt{\gamma} n+\gamma n$, we obtain

$$
\sum_{i=2}^{r} f_{i} \leqslant(t-1)((b-1) n+r \sqrt{\gamma} n+\gamma n) \leqslant(t-1)(b-1) n+\sqrt[3]{\gamma} n
$$

Since $Z^{\prime \prime} \cup W^{\prime \prime}=\varnothing$, (4.7) becomes $e(G) \leqslant t_{r}(k) n^{2}+\sum_{i \in[r]}\left(f_{i}+\beta_{i}+e_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}\right)-\alpha_{i}\right)$. Recall that $\sum_{i=1}^{r} \beta_{i} \leqslant 2 r^{2} C_{0} \sqrt{\gamma} n$ by (4.8). Together with (4.18) and (4.19), we derive that

$$
e(G) \leqslant t_{r}(k) n^{2}+z_{t}(n)+(t-1)(b-1) n+\sqrt[3]{\gamma} n+2 r^{2} C_{0} \sqrt{\gamma} n-\varepsilon n / 2<g(n, r, k, t)
$$

as $\gamma \ll \varepsilon$. This is a contradiction.
Let $L_{1} \cup L_{2} \cup L_{3}$ be a partition of $[2, r]$ such that $i \in L_{1}$ if and only if $\left|\tilde{Z}_{i}\right|<n, i \in L_{2}$ if and only if $\left|\tilde{Z}_{i}\right|=n$, and $i \in L_{3}$ if and only if $\left|\tilde{Z}_{i}\right|>n$. The following properties hold for $L_{1}, L_{2}$ and $L_{3}$.
(R1) If $i \in L_{1}$, then $Z_{i}^{j} \neq \varnothing$ for some $j \neq i$. By (Q2), we have $i \in L$ and, by Claim 4.10, $\tilde{Z}_{i}=Z_{i}^{i} \subsetneq V_{i}$ and $W_{i}^{\prime} \subseteq V_{q_{i}}$.
(R2) If $i \in L_{2}$, then $\tilde{Z}_{i}=Z_{i}^{i}=V_{i}$. Indeed, otherwise $\tilde{Z}_{i} \neq Z_{i}^{i}$, then $\left|Z_{i}^{i}\right|<n$ and $Z_{i}^{j} \neq \varnothing$ for some $j \neq i$. By (Q2) and Claim 4.10, we have $\tilde{Z}_{i}=Z_{i}^{i}$, a contradiction.
(R3) If $i \in L_{3}$, then $\tilde{Z}_{i} \nsubseteq Z_{i}$ (otherwise $\left|\tilde{Z}_{i}\right| \leqslant n$ ). By Claim 4.10, we have $\left|W_{i}\right|<2 \varepsilon n$, which implies that $Z_{i}^{j}=\varnothing$ for $j \neq i$ by $(Q 2)$. Thus, $Z_{i}^{i}=Z_{i}=V_{i} \subsetneq \tilde{Z}_{i}$.
Now we derive our final bound on $e(G)$. Write $z_{i}:=\left|\tilde{Z}_{i}\right|$ and $w_{i}:=\left|W_{i}^{\prime}\right|$ for $i \in[r]$.
By Claim 4.3 and the fact that $Z^{\prime \prime} \cup W^{\prime \prime}=\varnothing$, we have

$$
e(G)=e\left(G^{\prime}\right)+\sum_{i \in[r]} e_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{i}\right) \leqslant t_{r}(k) n^{2}+\sum_{i \in[r]}\left(\beta_{i}-\alpha_{i}+e_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{i}\right)\right)
$$

Moreover, as $a=1$, (4.5) becomes $e_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}^{\prime}\right) \leqslant \alpha_{i}$. It follows that $e_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{i}\right)=f_{i}+e_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}\right) \leqslant f_{i}+\alpha_{i}$. For $i \in\{1\} \cup L_{1} \cup L_{2}$, we simply use $f_{i}$ as the upper bound and thus we get

$$
e_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{i}\right)-\alpha_{i} \leqslant f_{i} \leqslant \begin{cases}z_{t}\left(z_{1}, w_{1}\right) & \text { if } i=1 \text { by (4.15) } \\ (t-1) \min \left\{z_{i}, w_{i}\right\} & \text { if } i \in L_{1} \text { by }(R 1) \text { and Claim 4.9 (2) } \\ (t-1)\left(z_{i}-n+w_{i}\right) & \text { if } i \in L_{2} \text { by }(R 2) \text { and (4.11) }\end{cases}
$$

Additional work is needed for $i \in L_{3}$. We let $\lambda=\max \left\{0,\left|L_{1}\right|-\left|L_{3}\right|\right\}$ and for $i \in L_{3}$, let $\lambda_{i}$ be the number of indices $j \in L_{1}$ such that $Z_{j}^{i} \neq \varnothing$. By $(R 1)-(R 3)$, we know that if $Z_{j}^{i} \neq \varnothing$, then $i \in L_{3}$ and $j \in L_{1}$. This implies that $\lambda_{i} \geqslant 1$ for every $i \in L_{3}$, and $\sum_{i \in L_{3}} \lambda_{i} \geqslant\left|L_{1}\right|$, yielding that

$$
\sum_{i \in L_{3}}\left(\lambda_{i}-1\right) \geqslant \lambda
$$

Recall that $G\left[t Z_{i} \backslash Z_{1}^{i}\right]$ is $K_{1, t}$-free by Claim 4.9 (2). Since $Z_{i}^{i}=Z_{i}$ is an independent set, it follows that $e_{G}\left(\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash Z_{1}^{i}\right) \leqslant(t-1)\left|\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash\left(Z_{i} \cup Z_{1}^{i}\right)\right|$. Together with (4.11), this gives

$$
e_{G}\left(\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash Z_{1}^{i}\right)+e_{G}\left(Z_{1}^{i}, Z_{i}\right) \leqslant(t-1)\left|\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash\left(Z_{i} \cup Z_{1}^{i}\right)\right|+(t-1)\left|Z_{1}^{i}\right|=(t-1)\left(z_{i}-n\right)
$$

Therefore, for $i \in L_{3}$, writing $\varrho_{i}:=e_{T}\left(Z_{1}^{i}, \tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash\left(Z_{i} \cup Z_{1}^{i}\right)\right)$, we have

$$
e_{G}\left(\tilde{Z}_{i}\right)=e_{G}\left(\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash Z_{1}^{i}\right)+e_{G}\left(Z_{1}^{i}, Z_{i}\right)+e_{G}\left(Z_{1}^{i}, \tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash\left(Z_{i} \cup Z_{1}^{i}\right) \leqslant(t-1)\left(z_{i}-n\right)+\varrho_{i}\right.
$$

Moreover, the definition of $\alpha_{i}$ implies that

$$
\begin{aligned}
e_{G}\left(W_{i}^{\prime}\right)+e_{G}\left(\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}, W_{i}^{\prime}\right)-\alpha_{i} & \leqslant e_{T}\left(W_{i}^{\prime}\right)+\left|\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}\right|\left|W_{i}^{\prime}\right|-\alpha_{i}=-e_{T}\left(\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}\right) \\
& =-\varrho_{i}-e_{T}\left(\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash\left(Z_{i} \cup Z_{1}\right)\right) \\
& \leqslant-\varrho_{i}-\binom{\lambda_{i}}{2} \leqslant-\varrho_{i}+1-\lambda_{i}
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally, by (4.11), we have $e_{G}\left(Z_{i}, W_{i}^{\prime}\right) \leqslant(t-1) w_{i}$ for $i \in L_{3}$. Combining all these inequalities together, we obtain that, for $i \in L_{3}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
e_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{i}\right)-\alpha_{i} & =e_{G}\left(\tilde{Z}_{i}\right)+e_{G}\left(Z_{i}, W_{i}^{\prime}\right)+e_{G}\left(W_{i}^{\prime}\right)+e_{G}\left(\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}, W_{i}^{\prime}\right)-\alpha_{i} \\
& \leqslant(t-1)\left(z_{i}-n+w_{i}\right)+\left(1-\lambda_{i}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows that $\sum_{i \in L_{3}}\left(e_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{i}\right)-\alpha_{i}\right) \leqslant \sum_{i \in L_{3}}(t-1)\left(z_{i}-n+w_{i}\right)-\lambda$ by using (4.20).
Using $\sum_{i=2}^{r}\left(z_{i}-n\right)=n-z_{1}$ and $\sum_{i=2}^{r} w_{i}=b n-w_{1}$, we derive that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{i \in L_{1}} \min \left\{z_{i}, w_{i}\right\}+\sum_{i \in L_{2} \cup L_{3}}\left(z_{i}-n+w_{i}\right) & =\sum_{i \in L_{1}} \min \left\{n-w_{i}, n-z_{i}\right\}+\sum_{i=2}^{r}\left(z_{i}-n+w_{i}\right) \\
& =\sum_{i \in L_{1}} \min \left\{n-w_{i}, n-z_{i}\right\}+b n-w_{1}+n-z_{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{i=2}^{r}\left(e_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{i}\right)-\alpha_{i}\right) & \leqslant \sum_{i \in L_{1}}(t-1) \min \left\{z_{i}, w_{i}\right\}+\sum_{i \in L_{2} \cup L_{3}}(t-1)\left(z_{i}-n+w_{i}\right)-\lambda \\
& =(t-1)\left(b n-w_{1}+n-z_{1}\right)+\sum_{i \in L_{1}}(t-1) \min \left\{n-w_{i}, n-z_{i}\right\}-\lambda
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally, we work on the $\beta_{i}$ 's and recall that $\beta_{i}=\sum_{j \in L \backslash\{i\}}\left|Z_{j}^{i}\right|\left(\left|\tilde{Z}_{j} \backslash Z_{j}\right|+\left|W_{j}^{\prime}\right|-n+\left|Z_{i} \backslash \tilde{Z}_{i}\right|\right)$. For $i \in$ $\{1\} \cup L_{1} \cup L_{2}$, as $\tilde{Z}_{i} \backslash Z_{i}=\varnothing, \beta_{i}=0$. For $i \in L_{3}$, as $\left|W_{i}\right|<2 \varepsilon n$, we have $Z_{i} \backslash \tilde{Z}_{i}=\varnothing$; for any $j \in L \backslash\{i\}$, we have $\tilde{Z}_{j} \backslash Z_{j}=\varnothing$ and $W_{j}^{\prime} \subseteq V_{q_{j}}$ again by Claim 4.10. Hence $\beta_{i}=\sum_{j \in L \backslash\{i\}}\left|Z_{j}^{i}\right|\left(\left|W_{j}^{\prime}\right|-n\right) \leqslant 0$

because $\left|W_{j}^{\prime}\right| \leqslant n$. It then follows that (noting that $L \cap L_{3}=\varnothing$ )

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{i \geqslant 1} \beta_{i} & =\sum_{i \in L_{3}} \beta_{i}=\sum_{i \in L_{3}} \sum_{j \in L \backslash\{i\}}\left|Z_{j}^{i}\right|\left(\left|W_{j}^{\prime}\right|-n\right) \\
& =\sum_{j \in L} \sum_{i \in L_{3} \backslash\{j\}}\left|Z_{j}^{i}\right|\left(\left|W_{j}^{\prime}\right|-n\right)=\sum_{j \in L}\left(n-z_{j}\right)\left(w_{j}-n\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that $1 \in L$ by (4.16) and $\left(n-z_{1}\right)\left(w_{1}-n\right) \leqslant 0$ by Claim 4.8. Furthermore, since $n-z_{j}=0$ for $j \in L_{2}$, it follows that $\sum_{i \geqslant 1} \beta_{i}=\sum_{j \in L_{1}}\left(n-z_{j}\right)\left(w_{j}-n\right)$.

Recall that $e_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{1}\right)=f_{1} \leqslant z_{t}\left(z_{1}, w_{1}\right)$. By (E3), we have $z_{t}\left(z_{1}, w_{1}\right)+(t-1)\left(n-z_{1}+n-w_{1}\right) \leqslant z_{t}(n)$. Thus, combining these estimates together, by (4.7), we get

$$
e(G) \leqslant t_{r}(k) n^{2}+\sum_{i \in[r]}\left(e_{G}\left(\tilde{U}_{i}\right)-\alpha_{i}+\beta_{i}\right) \leqslant t_{r}(k) n^{2}+z_{t}(n)+(t-1)(b-1) n+y-\lambda
$$

where $y:=\sum_{i \in L_{1}}\left((t-1) \min \left\{n-w_{i}, n-z_{i}\right\}-\left(n-z_{i}\right)\left(n-w_{i}\right)\right)$. For each $i \in L_{1}$, let $y_{i}:=$ $\min \left\{n-w_{i}, n-z_{i}\right\}$ and $y_{i}^{\prime}:=\max \left\{n-w_{i}, n-z_{i}\right\}$. Then $y_{i} \leqslant y_{i}^{\prime}$ and thus,

$$
(t-1) \min \left\{n-w_{i}, n-z_{i}\right\}-\left(n-z_{i}\right)\left(n-w_{i}\right)=y_{i}\left(t-1-y_{i}^{\prime}\right) \leqslant\left\lfloor(t-1)^{2} / 4\right\rfloor \leqslant 1
$$

Since $L_{1} \subseteq L \backslash\{1\}$, we have $\left|L_{1}\right| \leqslant b-1$. Moreover, by Claim 4.10, we have $w_{i} \leqslant\left|W_{i}\right|+\left|W_{i}^{\prime} \backslash W_{i}\right| \leqslant$ $2 \varepsilon n+\gamma n \leqslant 3 \varepsilon n$ for each $i \in L_{3}$. If $\left|L_{1} \cup L_{2}\right| \leqslant b-2$, then

$$
b n=\sum_{i \in[r]}\left|W_{i}\right| \leqslant n+(b-2) n+(r-b+1) \cdot 3 \varepsilon n<b n
$$

a contradiction. This implies $\left|L_{1} \cup L_{2}\right| \geqslant b-1$, and $\left|L_{3}\right| \leqslant r-b$. Since $\left|L_{1}\right|-\lambda=\min \left\{\left|L_{1}\right|,\left|L_{3}\right|\right\} \leqslant$ $\left|L_{3}\right| \leqslant r-b$, it follows that $\left|L_{1}\right|-\lambda \leqslant \min \{b-1, r-b\}$. Consequently, as $\left[(t-1)^{2} / 4\right] \leqslant 1$, we get

$$
y-\lambda \leqslant\left|L_{1}\right|\left[(t-1)^{2} / 4\right]-\lambda \leqslant \min \{b-1, r-b\}\left[(t-1)^{2} / 4\right]
$$

Together with (4.21), it gives the desired bound $e(G) \leqslant t_{r}(k) n^{2}+z_{t}(n)+(t-1)(b-1) n+\min \{b-$ $1, r-b\}\left[(t-1)^{2} / 4\right]=g(n, r, k, t)$. This completes the proof of Theorem 3 for $k<2 r$.

abstract:
In this paper we study a multi-partite version of the Erd\H{o}s--Stone
theorem. Given integers $r<k$ and $t\ge 1$, let $\text{ex}_k(n, K_{r+1}(t))$ be
the maximum number of edges of $K_{r+1}(t)$-free $k$-partite graphs with $n$
vertices in each part, where $K_{r+1}(t)$ is the complete $(r+1)$-partite graph
with $t$ vertices in each part. We determine the exact value of $\text{ex}_k(n,
K_{r+1}(t))$ for $t\le 3$, $r<k\le 2r$ and sufficiently large $n$. We also
characterize all extremal graphs for $r, k$ such that $r$ divides $k$,
analogous to a result of Erd\H os and Simonovits on forbidding $K_{r+1}(t)$ in
general graphs.
